Place is beautiful, architecture is stunning, lovely nature and greenery everywhere, not to mention the weather even in winter is an easy 15 degrees. I come back to the UK and it’s pissing it down with rain, as usual. Not far from the airport, I’m driving home and going through some small town with not much there. A fairly shitty looking small 90s shopping centre, a couple of pubs and a school. I’m driving by these crummy, small, depressing looking row houses with literally fucking nothing of interest around.

I get out of my car to go grab a drink from the shop. As soon as I get out, a group of 5 or so chavvy little scumbags wearing balaclavas and tracksuits. I pass them off since I’m used to it and not particularly intimated by little toe-rags, still, not pleasant.

I get home and out of interest I look at how much houses were in that town. 350-400k. For fucking what? To live in a damp, shoddy shithole town full of scum, little to no sunny days, with nothing to do, all to work for the rest of my life to pay off a crummy old small shitbox?

That last hour solidified my beliefs and made it clear to me, how utterly shit this country is.

posts.sub: Just moved back to New York after living in Japan for three years. AMA
posts.com:
I lived in Japan for two and a half years and spent time in other parts of Asia. I do a VERY specific type of maintenance for a specialized server and got a job in Tokyo right before covid. Since I know many of you are weebs who have never had the chance to go to Japan, I will answer questions here. While I spent 90% of the time in Japan, I was able to travel around Asia as well.

Key takeaways:

1) Japan is hands down the best place for a white person to live in Asia, IF you have money. The food quality and safety is excellent. Prostitution, while more expensive than anywhere else in Asia, provides whores who know how to please you. Geisha culture has not been completely extinguished from modern Japanese culture so you can have some wonderful experiences with prostitutes, better than Europe and far better than anything in America.

What is very interesting about Japanese services and restaurants is that everyone specializes in one thing and does that for their entire life, becoming excellent at whatever they do. Since Japanese work so much (notice I did not say "hard" or "smart", but "much" meaning that they are forced to spend many hours at work even if it's unproductive), they highly value "experiences" such as eating out, shows, etc, whatever. This puts a very high pressure on the service industry to deliver quality, meaning that if you're a westerner living in Japan, making a lot and working relatively little due being in a specialized field, you get to reap immense benefits from their service industry. These services were designed for Japanese people to enjoy, for their OWN people, but due to globalization you can now siphon off the cream from their society for your own benefit. It's actually amazing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
2) One of the most fascinating aspects, to me, was Japan's racist and arrogant nature being derived from an inferiority complex rather an an superiority complex. While white/European "racism" comes from an actual superiority to other races in terms of cultural, scientific, and artistic achievement, Japan's racism and supreme arrogance comes from not wanting to be associated with Chinese culture, from which they are HEAVILY influenced by even to this day, and wanting to be accepted by Anglo-Saxon power. posts.com:
The two cities couldn’t be much more different. Have you ever been to either?

Bangkok is somewhat cheaper, somewhat dirtier, quite a lot hotter, much smoggier (although I’ve been told that there are seasonal air quality problems in TPE too, it was fairly clear on my two visits), and close to five times the size of Taipei. Taipei is a fairly large place, but Bangkok’s much closer to a megacity, and it feels like one. If you’re used to small towns or easily overwhelmed, BKK is probably going to be harder to deal with than Taipei, which is in large part relatively orderly where Bangkok can be chaotic.

Personally, I would rather live in Thailand (I was there for several years, including a year in Bangkok), but I think Taipei is an easier place by a lot of metrics. I prefer the food, and I enjoy a bit of chaos.

English proficiency isn’t particularly good in Thailand outside of relatively narrow tourist areas, and most Thai women are disinclined to date foreigners, in part because they don’t want to be mistaken for prostitutes, who are treated like absolute shit by locals. There are exceptions, including very rich girls, party girls, and girls with their hands out, but no matter what sexpats/sex tourists manage to convince themselves, being a white guy does NOT make you more attractive or interesting in Thailand in general.

Not 100% sure how much better the English is among average Taiwanese, as I’ve always been visiting an expat friend and his Taiwanese wife when I’ve been there, so I both met people who spoke English fairly well and had a handy translator, but my surface impressions are that the average proficiency levels among young people are at least a little higher. And although my sample size is small I had a clear impression that dating white folks isn’t as stigmatized there.

No idea about Taiwanese residency policies, but know that despite its popularity among laptop hobos, Thailand is explicitly not a digital nomad-friendly country.

I post this in every Vegas thread, but here goes,

For hiking, go to Red Rocks. Park at the Calico Basin parking area for free. Climb to the top. It's a crazy scramble up through crevices and over giant boulders.

Another awesome hike is the Arizona Hot Springs trail. You hike through a slot canyon. There are some awesome hot springs you can bath in. You can actually climb down all the way to the Colorado River.

For food, go to West Spring Mountain and eat in Chinatown. Hachi, Viet Noodle House, Ramen Sora, Ichiza are all amazing.

For gambling, I'd go downtown. The table limits are lower. You get more bang for your buck. Fremont Street at night is always fucking crazy fun for people watching. The best game in vegas is craps. Best odds and the most entertaining. Play the pass line and back up your bet with odds.

Weed is legal. Just buy your drugs at a legal weed store. Don't do business with drug dealers in vegas. You'll get murdered.

The Cirque shows are all pretty good. Ka is probably my favorite. One show is enough.

posts.com:
A few things I learnt from my trip:

Stock up on drinks and snacks at Walgreens or Target next to the MGM, don't buy any cans, bottles or snacks at a hotel.

Fremont Street and Circus Circus are both complete bitches to get to. Don't expect to walk to them or be able to get the monorail to them.

The buffets are terrible value for money now and half of them a "brunch" buffets which mean they're split between breakfast and lunch so the range suffers. Maybe do one for the novelty but just eat at regular restaurants for the rest, you'll get better food and you can still fill yourself up and have it come out cheaper.

If you're a light sleeper, either get some white noise generator or turn the fan on the AC up. Noisy drunk people and heavy doors that slam hard are a bitch.

Older and smaller strip hotels gaming floors either have eye watering levels of cigarette smoke or pump out huge amounts air freshener to counter it. If you're intending to use your hotel to game and can't deal with smoke, don't stay at one of the cheap "classic" strip hotels.

Comp drinks servers all but run past you in my experience. You have to be proactive or at least keep a look out to get drinks.

I ended up using the monorail far more than I was expecting. It's worth getting a multi-day ticket if you're at a hotel that has a station. There are various ways of getting discounts (MyVegas lets you exchange easy to get points for vouchers and the monorail vouchers are one of the better vouchers you can earn that isn't always out of stock).

Slots are low odds and low volatility (at least on the strip). Very unlikely they'll do anything other than slowly drain away your money.

Bluffing is a much smaller part of poker than you'd think. Call with OK hands, raise with good hands. You should be folding 75% of your hands at least. If you have a strong starting hand, don't limp. At lower limit tables the guy who raises first preflop (unless he gets re-raised) wins most hands

posts.com:
>>2395044
>Lowest possible volitility:
You play $1 and the reels come in $0.85 every single spin. Most of the money paid out by the slot goes on low wins

>Highest possible volitility:
Every 1,100,000 spins, it wins $1,000,000 and never wins outside of that. Most of the money paid up by the slot goes on high win

US slots are basically all low X bet wins. They may have $10,000 jackpots but they never pay out on low stakes and even if people play the max stakes of ~$4 you're still going to go an entire holiday never having seen anyone hit then (and a 2500x max win is considered low for a slot) . Most people will see a steady stream of < 10x wins and features that almost never go above 50x.

With low volitility, people play for a long time, but almost no one comes out with a profit. With high volilitility, people who don't win get their money drained quickly but a % of people leave the slots having had a massive win.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2386906
Rural Colombia is indeed gorgeous in many spots, and Costa Rica has some of the most beautiful concentrated nature I’ve ever seen anywhere, while being safer and easier to get around (although Colombia is mostly safer than its reputation nowadays too). Urban Colombia, however, despite a bit of grit and risk in some spots, is far more charming than urban Costa Rica—San Jose, through which you will have to pass, is an ugly shithole, and while nearly every other town in the country is somewhat more attractive they’re small and have limited historical or cultural interest, apart from Cartago, which has an OK little colonial center.

All that said, the food isn’t particularly good in either country IMO. There are a few local specialties that are worth eating once or twice, but I would say that both Colombian and Costa Rican cooking tend toward the heavy, greasy, and bland.

Mexico or especially Thailand are both far better places to eat as far as I’m concerned. I don’t know Puerto Vallarta specifically, but Mexican beaches I have visited in the Yucatán and Riviera Maya can be very nice if a bit resort/package tourism dominated.

I know Thailand very well—lived there for years—and will always love the place, but I encourage most people to go somewhere other than Bangkok first and see BKK on the way out. I love the place in a lot of ways but love almost everywhere else in the country more. It’s hot, smoggy, has miserable traffic, and isn’t especially attractive, so it can make a bad first impression, but it undeniably has a great deal going on. There are as many favorite beaches there as there are people, but I’ve had great times on Ko Samui (easy mode, avoid Chaweng Beach, which is sleazy and grubby); Phuket (even easier mode, avoid Patong Beach, which is sleazy and grubby and Russian Mafia, I like the southern tip of the island); Ko Chang (no airport so takes a bit longer to reach, mix of hippies and smaller resorts); and others.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2389185
The best way is to just not do it. Tell your GP before you go on the trip that you're going on a trip, and you need your prescription for the entire duration of the trip. Add one month or something (depends on the lenght of your trip) to make sure that even if you get delayed for whatever reason you're not left without your presciption.
There are ofc variables, like the majority of the world has cheaper meds than the USA. And also some meds are extremely illegal in some countries, so look it all up. Based on the main ingredient, not the brand name.
In some third world countries your solution might work great, and you might get what you need, for cheaper, too. But let's say you go to any Western country or any country with laws, their GPs will not care too much about your home prescription, they will want to do their own checks, and you might end up with some completely different meds than what you are used to. The only reason to bring your home prescription is in case customs wants to check why you have certain meds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2389484
I actually agree with all of your advice here, but
> go to any Western country or any country with laws, their GPs will not care too much about your home prescription, they will want to do their own checks, and you might end up with some completely different meds than what you are used to.

Isn’t necessarily true in my experience. A lot of European cities have walk-in travel clinics for foreigners that can sometimes fill prescriptions for visitors based on a foreign script, with relatively few questions asked. My wife accidentally ran out of thyroid meds while on holiday in Portugal once and was able to get what she needed from a clinic just by showing them the empty box with her name on the prescription label. And when I moved countries, I was able to get an armload of prescriptions from my new GP just by telling him the medications I needed (I have multiple chronic health conditions). That last case is different, of course, because it was implicit that I would have some kind of ongoing relationship with the doctor and he would eventually see blood work for me.

But assuming the medications involved aren’t dangerous or tightly controlled (probably wouldn’t work for anything psychoactive, definitely wouldn’t work for narcotics), it is often possible to get an emergency script from a foreign doctor in the west.

Still agree that the best option is to get a “vacation fill” of whatever you’re on to last as long as you will be away whenever possible, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I hate flying, going to be flying in a month from california to london, what's a drug that's guaranteed to knock me out cold the whole time? I'm awake at night a month ahead thinking about this flight, it's driving me crazy with anxiety. I want to try a few different medications before i go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391230
Ambien or another high-test hypnotic sleeping pill might do the trick. If you’re not concerned about potential abuse and addiction, you might also talk to a doctor about a small quantity of an anxiolytic like Xanax or Ativan, but any drug in the barbiturate or benzodiazepine families is more serious business than people like to think, and shouldn’t be used too casually. They’re all physically habit-forming with nasty withdrawal symptoms, and some people get unpleasant benzo hangovers that can leave you groggy and stupid for an extended period. They can, however, ameliorate anxiety symptoms very effectively in the short term, even if they don’t necessarily render you unconscious.

You should also think about jet lag—I agree with those experts who say that you should avoid trying to sleep at times when you wouldn’t be asleep at your destination while in transit. But it’s virtually impossible to do this perfectly, so if you need to conk out to survive a flight it’s not the end of the world even if it’s suboptimal.

If they haven’t already by the time I finish typing this, someone will surely suggest combining alcohol with one or more of the above. It might work, but I think it’s à fundamentally dumb idea—while alcohol can be good for making you pass out, it’s terrible for sleep quality, so it will make you less likely to stay asleep, and you’re likely to wake up unrested with a hangover in the middle of your flight.

I recommend looking up some anti-anxiety breathing exercises and guided meditation—it may sound like bullshit but in my experience as an anxious person it can also actually work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391241
I appreciate the help, i want some hardcore shit, i have all these thoughts of dying already and its a month till my flight, idk i never take any medication or pills of any kind, but im close to cancelling my flight out of fear and i need the assurance i can get something that will make me knock out for 10 hours. I appreciate the advice, i need to go see a doctor ASAP

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391241
Oh, and if you do end up going with a sleeping pill like Ambien or Lunesta, try it at home a few days before you fly to see how long it lasts in your case, so you can time your dosing appropriately. You will not enjoy dragging your ass through customs and immigration while still deeply under the influence of one of these drugs, nor do you want to still be comatose when you land.

Another psychoactive medication you might want to discuss with your doctor is trazodone; it’s an ancient antidepressant, but it also has some anti-anxiety and sedative properties and used to get prescribed for insomnia. I use a small dose daily at bedtime as part of a depression and anxiety regimen, and while I can’t say it knocks me out for ten hours, it does make me sleepy and I wake up more relaxed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391732
>Any tips on motion sickness pills? Never had them
Many of the OTC ones are based on dimenhydrinate; seems to work OK for my kids. Can make you a bit sleepy but not enough to be used as a sedative. It’s a dissociative/quasi-hallucinogen in the case of massive overdose or deliberate abuse by bored teenagers. Don’t drink alcohol while taking it, less for side effects and more because it seems to stop it from working almost completely.

You can also get scopolamine pills or patches, although these may be script-only depending on where you live; my uncle, who liked deep sea fishing but could also barf walking through a puddle, depended on these.

Another Rx-only drug that in my limited experience might be the most powerful is Ondansetron, AKA Zofran, which can even keep chemotherapy patients from upchucking. My wife got it once in the ER when she had debilitating nausea and she stopped throwing up in seconds, although she had it as an injection rather than a tablet. Not sure if it’s given often for self-administration.

Copper-alloy wristbands and similar talismans work only if you are highly responsive to placebo effects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391812
Still here, still in India (although my wife and I are moving to the U.S. in the very near future).

Urban India is modernizing. Educated middle-class Indians have far better earning opportunities than their parents' generation. You'll find many younger people who live very Western-influenced lives. Nevertheless, these people represent a minority of the overall population, even in large cities.

Rural India is much different, and it's incredibly easy to find scenes similar to those depicted in the OP. I have very recently visited insurgency-affected regions of East-Central India wherein I met and spoke to tribal people who had never even heard of "America." It's not especially difficult to step away from modernity here.

I think, to a great extent, much of this "traditional charm" is directly correlated with socioeconomic inequality, poverty, and lack of educational attainment. India still has a distinctive culture, and this culture is apparent and practiced even in wealthier households. I live in a pretty middle-class neighborhood, and there's never a moment I don't doubt or realize that I'm in India (right now, for instance, there's a neighborhood mela and festival ongoing--I am being forced to listen to literally window-shaking devotional music while people scream, shriek, and dance on the road).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393667
cont.
As India's economy continues to somewhat strengthen, these visible indicators of inequality will--most probably--become less visible. But I don't think that's going to happen any time soon. India isn't going to magically transform into an unrecognizable destination overnight. The next several decades will doubtlessly bring some improvements, but I doubt India is going to become a Westernized or entirely modern country in our lifetimes.

(it's also worth noting that the current political landscape in many states is dominated by Hindu nationalist parties and politicians, almost all of whom are opposed to so-called Westernization, at least when such Westernization doesn't impact their personal earning opportunities)

>>2391822
In respect to clothes and whatnot: this is very, very prevalent, especially in rural areas.

I do think it's worth noting that Western dress among men is very widespread. Even villagers in the middle of bumfuck nowhere often wear t-shirts and jeans. Traditional dress isn't commonly worn except by persons working in certain professions and for special occasions (again, there are many exceptions--I haven't spent as much time in South India as I have elsewhere, but I think farmers and whatnot customarily and very regularly wear lungis. Lower-income Muslim men are another very noticeable exception, as many wear typically Islamic clothing).

(again, can't generalize. I wouldn't bat an eye at a guy wearing a lungi or dhoti in many neighborhoods. It's not uncommon at all)

The trend is different for women. Indian women in cities often wear "ethnic" clothing. Outside of cities, the overwhelming majority of women almost exclusively wear saris and other traditional garments.

How do people manage to make time for long trips? I mean stuff like 2+ weeks, going into even the months territory.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393161
Brazil has about 50k murders per year. That said, most murders are related to drug/gang problems and take place in poor neighborhoods that you should not go as a foreigner. so it's not likely.
The problem is robbery. Sometimes people get shot by the robber, whether because they tried to react and failed or just because the criminal felt like killing the victim. That's what you should be afraid as a foreigner.
Still, it's unlikely. Everyone I know and that live in a big city either has been robbed at least once or has a close friend/relative that was.
I was robbed once. I'm 30 yo and weekly got drunk and waited late night in the street for my uber to arrive, though. So, statistically speaking, it's very unlikely for a foreigner that spends a few weeks here to be robbed.
But yes, it can happen and compared to european cities brazilian cities are very dangerous. Don't think that's enough to make you decide not to travel here, though.
Just don't wear jewelry, waches, don't flash cash and use your phone in a discreet manner.
Is Brazil a good option to just chill, where you can simply go as you wish without putting yourself into danger? No, there are much better places; even in poor countries.
But you will be fine if you're not stupid and you're travelling as a single man or in a small group of friends. Brazilians naturally develop some kind of street smart but you should be fine if you're not clueless and act like if you were in Norway.
Also, stay in hotels or rent Airbnbs in apartment buildings or houses in gated communities. Do not rent regular houses. Even though the risk of something happening is not that high, better not to gamble with it.

Rio and SP have lots of motorcycle robberies. And traffick really sucks. Easy to park, though.
>>2393406
Nowadays in Rio and SP a cheap meal will cost you 50 reais, a good one about 100-120 up to few hundred reais. Mcdonalds would cost about 40 reais.
A 330ml heineken bottle in a market will cost you about 5, 10 in a cheap bar, 15 in a expensive bar. In expensive nightclubs 2-3x that. A black label whisky shot about 40.
An uber ride for 5km will cost you about 25-30 reais. A subway ticket is about 5 reais in SP, the same price of a bus.
Locals are very friendly towards foreigners. No one will target you for being american. You could get hustled to buy something from street vendors, specially in Rio, for a higher price. But that's pretty much it.
In southern regions I recommend Iguazu Falls (3 days is enough) for nature (much better than shitty niagara falls) and Florianopolis to chill on the beach and party. In the state of SP there is Ilhabela. In the state of Minas Gerais, there ae some nice colonial towns like Ouro Preto and Tiradentes (just to spend a full day in each). In the state of Rio de Janeiro, Angra dos Reis (if you have money to charter a boat; there are more than 1000 beaches and 360 islands) and Paraty (also a colonial town and boat related stuff).
In northeastern region there are lots of beach resorts. If you want to see the most african city in Brazil and our first capital, go to Salvador. Besides that, I only recommend Lençois Maranhenses.
In northern region Manaus (2 days at most) and some jungle resort in the Amazon. Also there is Jalapão.
In center west region, there is Pantanal, a wetland. Not much to do besides seeing animals and flora.
Cooming is good. Better if you are in good shape, specially in Rio. And greater if you're white, tall, blond, blue eyed.
Brazilian women are easy and attracted to foreigners. Hookers (from good places) provide a girlfriend experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393841
Try feijoada, pastel, coxinha, comida de boteco (bar food), rodizio (all you can eat meat)...
The country is huge so depends of where you going. But I would say the best months in southeastern states are april-june and september-november. Not too hot or cold and not too much rain. In São Paulo it can get near 0 C, but usually 5-10C in cold winter days and 35C in hot summer days. Rio get 15C in cold days and 40+C in hot summer days. Bear in mind that 10C in Brazil is much colder than 3C in European countries. We usually do not have heating inside houses and shops so it does feel cold.
I just advise to rent a car if you want to travel to smaller cities like from SP to southern MG and Paraty. Inside cities just use uber/taxi. If you go from capital to capital just fly.
Not really sure about hotels. Like anywhere else I just look for the ratings, location and hotel class. You won't have a problem booking 4+ stars hotels. If you're looking for cheap places, take care. We have motels (love hotels) that are used for having sex and places that attract low level scum to use drugs. So just book good places. 50-100 usd gets you great places in most cities and 100-200 usd gets you 5 star hotels in the expensive cities.
About the water, it depends of the state you are. I have friends that drink tap water. I do not, even though it seems that the water where I live is good for drinking. I would advise you to buy water instead. In Rio you definetely would not want to drink from the tap.

>>2397542
Not that poster but I'm Colombian and I've been to both.
The thing that struck me the most in Medellín is how blatant social inequality is. Yes, seeing beggars digging through trash containers is a common sight everywhere in the country, but Medellín takes it to another level.
Thing is, most Colombian cities have clear divisions according to Estrato, you have no-go zones and you have rich and safe neighbourhoods, I could see it in my home city (Ibagué), I could see it in Bogotá, where you see utter post-apocalyptic shitholes like Calle 22 around Santa Fe, and very nice areas such as Chico or Cedritos up north, that make you feel like you're walking through a safe and clean European neighbourhood (I've been to Europe).
In Medellin, on the other hand, even the areas that are supposed to be "high-class" and touristy like El Poblado are still full of unsavory characters - I stopped somewhere to eat some empanadas and in 5 minutes there were like 5 different bums that passed by digging through the trash can besides me. One of them ended up cursing at me for not giving him money.
I felt unsafe as fuck in Plaza Botero, imagine my surprise when I saw such a buttload of homeless people and streetwalking hookers hanging around right there in the middle of it, mixed up with white collar workers, average joes and tourists. It was a shocking sight.
In Bogotá you feel very unsafe in some places, while very safe in others, this rule also applies to most other big Colombian cities I've been to. In Medellín you feel unsafe everywhere.
I got the feeling Medellín is still in a "transition" phase of sorts, I hear it's becoming quite prosperous and doing well economically, but I think exactly because of this accelerated development that social matters aren't really keeping up and extreme poverty and prosperity are co-existing everywhere.
The best parts of my trip to Medellín were the times when I *wasn't* in Medellín, such as Guatapé and Santa Fe de Antioquia.

With the exception of the Northwestern part of the state near Erie, the weather isn't terrible, but it's not great either. The Philadelphia area gets more sun but it gets pretty hot and humid in spring and summer. The Pittsburgh area tends to be overcast, wet, and snowy, mild in spring and summer. East of the mountains gets Mid-Atlantic currents and West of the mountains gets some lake effect from the Great Lakes. Property values vary so much across the state. >>2382956
Amherst native here, just got back from spending Christmas in the area. I agree that it’s got a hell of a lot going for it for a relatively small town, but would argue that nearby Northampton has a better and more walkable downtown core. I have a midsized gang of childhood friends who either stayed in or returned to the area, and nearly all of them drive all the time; those who don’t are mostly hardcore bicyclists.

Desirable housing can also be expensive relative to local incomes—people I know who have bought homes in the area recently have ended up in Hadley (mostly not at all walkable) and Easthampton (only a few central walkable square blocks), or farther out into the (decidedly non-walkable) hilltowns, rather than being comfortably able to afford either Amherst or Noho. Perhaps rents for the new construction apartments in downtown Amherst aren’t bad, though; I dunno.

>>2382821
I had a good time in Madison, Wisconsin, when I went to grad school there. The central isthmus is dense and walkable, and less-central neighborhoods are mostly bikeable. And it wasn’t terribly expensive when I lived there (cheaper than MA), but I assume there are many more expensive new condo/apartment developments downtown that could have driven COL/rents up. So depending on where you are now it might or might not be affordable. But it’s not big-city expensive despite almost feeling like a city.

I am subscribed to quite a lot of quality channels. Some well known travel vloggers and some touristy/theme park/coaster channels that deserve more subscribers. Here's a list of the ones i watch the most:

Brit who has done videos with Bald but is way more likeable and relatable to the average traveler

Goth freaks but interesting vids & niche movie-related sights

German vlogger who comes off as genuine/authentic and has honest opinions

>>2389962
You've never attempted hiking in Korea, then. I do not like the Korean style of hiking, like it's just straight paths up the mountain, and then down the mountain. But there's a lot of that style of hiking, and hiking is insanely popular. There's everyone from the kids who are forced by their schools to go on the mountain and collect trash (they're bored af cause there's virtually no trash to collect). There's hordes of old ladies who hike with backpacks bigger than themselves, AND who are always gonna be faster than you, no matter how fast you are. (Their stamina is insane.) There's also tons of couples always with girls hating themselves for ever agreeing to hiking, and the guys just quietly plotting breakup. lol I always had fun, though, those straight ass paths are a good challenge. The views are indeed not as amazing as most everywhere else in Asia, but they still have some forests and all.

Note that you really have to bring a whole day of supplies. The internet connection is great as per usual, but there isn't much more infrastructure on most mountains than just internet. This can also mean no water, so bring water, too. Obviously delpends on the mountain. A pro compared to hiking in some of the US is that you won't run into wild animals that would be dangerous for humans.

Hong Kong on the other hand is as cyberpunk as a human city can get in real life.

There is no photoshop in this image. This is Mong kok, the most densely populated neighborhood in the world. This vicinity all the way to the south feels like you're in basically Night City (or rather, NC feels like HK). posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2381428
It really all depends on your tastes, anon. But if you want the most bang for your buck, plan a trip to do two of these cities at the same time. For example, the ferry from HK to Macau is only 40 bucks (roundtrip) and Shenzhen is right at the border. So you could like, leave a day or two for visiting Macau and do the rest of the week in Hong Kong visiting the city, museums, the nearby greenery or simply just having fun. Same goes for Singapore and Kuala lumpur, a simple bus trip of a few hours gets you from one to the other.

Same goes for Japan. Kyoto and Osaka (+kobe) are basically the same city. only issue is if you want to do Tokyo too, in which case an overnight bus trip (500km) won't cost much. And Same goes for Seoul/Busan (300km)
Taking this into account, you can easily see that HK/Shenzhen/Macau is a great deal and so is Kyoto/Osaka/Kobe (kobe is definitely worth a visit !), especially if you can fit Tokyo into your timetable/budget. I'd also put Malacca/Kuala Lumpur/Singapore as another trio worth visiting.

On the other hand, there are places where it's worth just taking 2-4 weeks, find an appartment or airbnb to rent, and pretend you've lived there all your life. These places are Chongqing and Taipei, in my opinion. They're relatively peaceful places with not much shit to do but basically go on a walking adventure around the city, discover the people, hear their stories. Maybe have a love story. Maybe look at the job situation so you can make it there. Who knows.

>Beijing
Huge roads, not walkable, shit public transport, gray, businesses mostly in big ass malls, shit nightlife (as in, night street food, night restaurants etc). Very restrictive so not many small things going on.

>Tokyo
Small streets everywhere, businesses everywhere even in the tiniest corner. There’s always something to do.

>Osaka
See Tokyo but more chaotic, friendlier, less autistic and more night things going on.

>kyoto
Classier and more orderly than Osaka. High-end culture.

>Taipei
A mix of the best of both worlds (Japan and China), reminiscent of Hong Kong in some ways but less chaotic, more laid back.

>Seoul
Only went there in the 90s. Not very interesting back then.

>HK
Very “cyberpunk”. Very rich and poor mingle together. Businesses everywhere, almost impossible to see darkness in the central parts. Closest you’ll get.

>Macau
Discount Hong Kong with much much less life going on. Went there in the late 90s though.

>Chongqing
Memed by youtube videos. No idea why this city is brought up all the time. Many cities are similar to this one, part of the recent trend of newly invested cities such as Hangzhou.

>Shanghai
My personal favourite but not because of how “cyberpunk” it feels. It’s a city with a lot of life, good blend of modernity and (not so old) history.

Here's the Cyberpunk rankings of the cities I've visited so far:

Tokyo (7/10) (overated- too clean and tidy)
Seoul (7/10) (overated- has too much of a boring American "grid" like layout)
Busan (8/10) (underated- multiple skyscraper urban cores tucked in between mountains and hills filled with favela looking "slums", good mix of grit and modern/sleek)
Kyoto (0/10) (Asking if Kyoto is Cyberpunk is like asking if Florence, Italy is Cyberpunk. No.)
Jakarta (6/10) (too "low life" and not enough "high tech", its just a giant open sewer slum with some high end shopping malls in the center)

Some others
Bangkok (9/10) (100% Blade Runner/Night City, my favorite on this list, only reason its not a 10 is because I havent been to China yet which I imagine would take all perfect 10/10 rankings)
Saigon (8/10) (the "low life" aspect among neon grit is well represented, but a little lacking in the balance of modern infrastructure, skyscrapers and urban verticality outside of a very small area of District 1- give it time though, the city is building up fast and will probably take a 10/10 spot some day)

Keep in mind, this was all before COVID though- 2018 and 2019- and I imagine lockdowns killed any sort of that Cyberpunk "wild west", hustle and bustle feeling these places used to have. I imagine theyre all a lot quieter now and all the small businesses are mostly shuttered.

posts.com:
Some of the cities mentioned in this thread are too 'clean' to be cyberpunk. More like cyberpop. Look for cities that have large slums; the more populated the slums, the more likely it is to become cyberpunk, as the slums begin to stack on top one another. Bonus points if it's next to high rise skyscrapers in a densely packed area. Also, look at rapidly developing countries which are industrial & thus are very polluted. The destruction of the environment is a major trope in cyberpunk; places with lots of smog, terrible weather, rivers of trash, e-waste will definitely fit this.

Other tropes are the feeling of isolation in a densely packed area, orwellian surveillance and the 'sin city' factor, especially if it's open-air/ungoverned/state sanctioned.
Think the 7 sins:

Lust: escorts, massage parlors, love hotels, easy access p0rn, hypersexuality, gay bath houses, ladyboys
Gluttony: fast food, binge drinking, gold plated food, silver facials, excessive materialism/consooming
Greed: crypto, casinos/gambling, stock market, hustlers, gig economy, cash4gold, various scams, black market (silk road, organ harvesting),
Sloth: high automation, widespread apathy/nihilism, indifference to cruelty/bystander effect (watching people die, ignoring untouchables), promoting laziness
Wrath: war propaganda, political/ethnic/religious scapegoats blasted on media, eye 4 an eye mentality, cheering on violent/self-destructive behavior, sanctioned gangrapes, crimewave, gangs, police brutality, rudeness
Envy: sports cars, bling, expensive bags, photoshopped models, paradise packages, high rise condos next to slums, celebrities
Pride: social media, taking pride in degeneracy, ethno-narcissism, hyper-nationalism, religious zealots, promoting vanity

Which cities come to mind? Next time you re in a big city, look around for the 7 sins and tropes such as class disparity, pollution, industrialization, automation, overpopulation etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You can find a lot of information/guides on Google desu but I'll try to answer your questions.
>how do i find a good place to live
Lots of websites like booking.com or hostel world can help you find a place, although some would argue you might get better deals on websites directly. I wouldn't stress too much unless you're desperately trying to save money.
>how do i learn important customs in the place i visit/how do i not act retarded.
Again, google can help you. Wikivoyage usually has some tips but there are lots of websites.
>How do i plan my stay?
Look at websites like wikivoyage, lonely planet, tripadvisor etc. Make a list of must do things and some optional stuff if you gave time. Don't over plan it, you should be able to be spontaneous, you never know what might come up. In terms of time, I typically plan 3 or 4 nights per place I'm staying - it can be more or less based on how much time I estimate I'll need.
>then there are also issues like transport
Again, you'll need to use resource websites like wikivoyage. If you're interested in Japan, the Japan general thread has resources in the OP.
Also, not to overwhelm you, but don't forget to look into visa requirements.

honestly the main issues I had while traveling alone was how to take a piss without leaving my luggage unattended or how to take a nap on a train without getting pickpocketed. As the other anon said, do research online and avoid 3rd world countries. for hotels I use booking.com but its also good idea to cross check reviews with google maps as you might see some opinions on google that are not on booking. also, I would recommend taking some meds unironically, I now always take with myself pills for allergy, something for fever and for food poisoning. Some suggestions I do have is to bring 2 phones and 2 wallets. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391137
>how to travel i have no idea wtf im doing
First thing's first, what's your budget (how much are you willing to spend total - $3000, $4000)? If you can't afford it then you can't go. Second, where are you going and for how long? You can split your budget by number of days and then check if you have enough money for accomodations, food, tourism, flight, transportation or if it will be unafforadble for you at which point you need to work more and delay your trip. You're from EU so that passport should open a lot of doors for you, some countries may still require you to apply for a visa so check before you buy a ticket if you need to or don't. Also, check restrictions on time limits for visa-free travel (can't go in visa free and stay indefinitely, many places have a 90 day limit).
>what about a place to stay?
hostels, airbnb's, cheap hotels, expensive hotels are all options. You want to focus on WHERE you want to stay. Staying "in tokyo" is not the same as staying "in akihabara in tokyo", you could be a massive distance apart from where you want to realistically spend most of your time. Look for accommodations within your budget in a zone you like, or just next to the zone you want to be in if it's not too far (or if public transport is close, available and reliable).
>what about customs?
dont need to know them for the most part, just know big ones (i.e. no alcohol in muslim countries, no drugs practically anywhere, no nudity in the streets) and just be polite. If you dress well and are polite, no one will bother you, if you fuck up a custom that people care for just apologize and ask for an explanation after telling them you didnt know. What you should know is that if strangers approach you for something, 99% chance its a scam. Strangers will help you, but usually only after YOU ask THEM for help.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391466 (cont.)
>how do i plan my stay?
Research, and lots of it. You have the internet available, so use it. You can go minimalist and winging it or you can make a full day by day itinerary where you pick certain stops per day and plan a route to visit all of them. If you search online you may find sample routes for places you want to go to which you can alter at will based on your own interests. Look up lists of landmarks, museums, historical sites, hidden gems, hot spots in town and then find out which ones you want to go to and which ones you can skip on. Once you know where to go, find ways to connect them. If they're all in a circle around your accommodation, divide that circle into quadrants and explore it in a loop so you hit your interests and see the town on the way to and back. You can even find quality restaurants ahead of time per area and go to those the day you head out. It's really no different from mapping out a day in your own town. Something like:
>want to go see city hall in my small town
>oh and there's a museum a few blocks away
>there's even a really beautiful park further down from the museum
>it's going to be around lunchtime when I go, theres a restaurant with great reviews between the museum and park so i can stop there
>after the park i'll need to make my way back, but ill return in a circle instead of a straight line back to check out a church and another museum before I leave
It's that simple, people really overestimate planning for travel. It takes a few hours at most to have everything ready, from bookings to day-to-day itineraries.

Speaking of bookings, do not use sites that book for you. Always book directly with an airline/hotel. If there's a problem and you book directly, then the place that fucked you has to deal with you themselves. If a booking agency fucks up, then you don't deal with the hotel or airline, you deal with the agency, which means you're fucked because they won't give you a fix when you need it, only after.

If you're worried about losing your phone, ask for a physical map and have the hotel circle their location so you can show that to a cab driver.

>>2391137
> I know i would be completely fucked if i bought an airline ticket today and winged it
What makes you say that? It's not hard to 'wing it'. The only things you really need to make sure of are:
>Visa requirements
Just google Japan entry requirements for UK citizen or wherever you're from
>Money + money exchange access
I recommend opening a wise account, it's just a debit card you send money to that can pay in 99% of currencies with very low fees (like 0.5%). Avoid using your home debit card, it's probably going to charge a whole lot more than you expect. Using wise card at the ATM is a good idea too, since cash exchanges charge stupid fees.
>Somewhere to stay on your first night out of the airport
Well, you simply don't want to be caught with nowhere to stay.

That's it. You're going to Japan and Korea, both very safe countries, there's no secret shit you need to learn. There are no secret cultural customs you should learn. You're (probably) a white guy, the japs aren't expecting you to know which side of the road to walk on.

On top of this, and most importantly. Allow yourself to be spontaneous.
If you are staying in a hostel (which I highly recommend) and someone invites to do something, it's probably a good idea to go. If someone says there going to some other city and you think it looks like a good place, then you should consider joining them even if it wasn't in your plans. When you're on a holiday you can afford to do that, what else have you got to do, work?
There are two types of people that I HATE when it comes to travelling: picky eaters and over-planners, or people who are too scared to stray from their plan.

Just know where you need to be for your flights, that's important. You might have a few ideas of where you'd like to go, but be flexible, transport and accommodation might not always be in your favour. Or, someone you meet will show you a better location.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391753
>Worried about people not speaking english
Google translate, just translate no more than 8-10 words at a time and use simplified english, it works better that way.
>I have to figure out public transport on my own
Typically easier than you imagine. I would be surprised if electronic ticket machines at train stations didn't have a button to display in English. Most developed countries have their public transport loaded on google maps, for longer bus rides that require privately owned transport, use rome2rio. A lot of cities have special 'bus card' things, I guarantee you can buy one of these at the airport with $15 pre loaded onto it.
>Aren't hostels expensive
Almost always cheaper than a hotel. I just searched for accommodation in tokyo on booking dot com and sorted by cheapest, the whole first page was all hostels. Besides, the opportunity to meet people by staying in hostels cannot be bought.

My other tip, take a backpack not wheeled luggage.

Basically Anon, you're 20 years old, you don't need the boring boomer-tier holiday where you have a private apartment your travel agent got you. What you need is a wild ride where you make last minute decisions, meet new people, leave them behind, go places you didn't even know existed, try foods you can't pronounce, walk through parts of the city where taxis don't go, have conversations with people you knew for 3 hours yet will remember forever and come back with photos that actually have interesting stories attached to them.
Would you rather show your friends back home a photo of a statue and say "this is just some old statue, I walked there and went home." or be able to say "I met these 2 american guys who were going to see this statue, so went and saw it with them. I really liked those guys, so I went with them to kyoto the next day."

did this at your age. went 3 weeks japan+korea and the backpacking to southeast asia. just got a flight to japan, then another to korea and from there to singapore. a few weeks before i booked an airbnb for the whole stay in korea and japan. just booking a hotel for a few days and then planning the rest after works too - i did it this summer in turkey. it was a bit stressful sometimes but it works. when i arrived in singapore at 6am in the morning without sleeping i had nothing booked or planned. literally had to find a hostel on booking.com while i was still at the airport but this worked out completely fine. the rest of the trip i pretty much planned on the go and everything worked out perfectly. traveling alone without planning much is one of the best experiences you ll have. in japan/korea you should probably plan a bit more tho. check what public transport is available and what kind of tickets are cheapest

what to bring aint deep: laptop, phone, cables, clothes, sunglasses, journal, a book, maybe a spare phone if you or a family member has an old one (for a sim card because you are likely to need your own sim card for bank/other accounts nowdays), laundry detergent for traveling, 1-2 thin towels, maybe some cash of the local currency, camera, dildo collection etc. etc.

also dont need to prepare anything really, just check if u need visa etc and maybe places where u wanna go. my tip is to go to hostels or do couchsurfing to meet new peope. find out what (dating) apps you can use to also meet locals. that s how you find out about places/trips you wouldnt have known before

>>2391717
>8k euros
good budget but depends on length of stay and luxuries you indulge in
>close to enough for 30 days in Tokyo?
I loosely planned a trip to Japan and found I'd spend around $5-6k on two weeks but $2k of that is the flight because burger. You really need to spend the time to crunch numbers because even though you have enough to go, you don't know if you have enough to go for 30 days. Some stuff will be more expensive too, so if you want to go to a ryokan or go to a hot spring town and get a hot spring hotel for a night, that will up pricing. You really need to budget before you go. As for 30 days in Tokyo, lmao you clearly didnt listen to us and try to plan shit out. You should be moving around since you're staying so long.
A good sample itinerary for you would be:
4 days Tokyo > daytrip to fuji > train to Kyoto and stay 5 days > train to Osaka and stay for 4 days > bus to the nakasendo trail and try to stay at a post town at the end of the hike > bus to Gero and stay a few days for hot spring relaxation > bus to takayama > daytrip to shirakawa-go > continue northeast or loop back to tokyo.

This is the way you should be thinking of your trip. You allocate days based on what you want to see per city/town and some time for travel within the country. The SIM card at the airport will be a must for internet on the go. Hostel vs. Hotel vs. Airbnb is subjective and depends on pricing. Some hotels are good and cheap enough to justify, especially if you like a private room and can be social without a hostel setting.

I disagree with bagpack only, i do wheeled carry on + normal sized bagpack (not the 55L shit) so that my clothes arent crumpled up messes on arrival and just keep it in my airbnb/hotel so I roam free and unencumbered.

>>2388417
Oh boy, yes I've got some memories in that place. Storytime:

>a while ago, several years before Fukushima nuclear disaster
>be me, 20yo weeb studying Jap in Tokyo
>holidays at my language school, bored af
>"hey anon, don't you like Ghibli? Did you know Miyazaki went to this island called Yakushima where he got inspired to make princess mononoke? maybe you can check it out, you can hike and shit"
>yeah that sounds dope
>never hiked in my life
>go to the Victoria outdoor goods store on the main road between Jimbocho and Ogawamachi stations
>spend a buttload of money on gourmet camping food because I don't want to starve in Yakushima island
>instant truffle risottos, dehydrated mutton ragu, all the fanciest food imaginable
>pick up a folding stove and gas canisters, venom extraction kits, basically enough supplies to last through the apocalypse
>pass a bicycle store on the way home
>see a cool looking folding bicycle
>hey this might come in useful, like how else would I get to the trail entrance from wherever the bus drops me off (spoiler - the bus drops you off directly at the trail entrance)
>get the bike, ride it home
>look in my wallet, realize I've just spent nearly all the money I have left for that month
>realize I didn't buy an actual backpack to carry all my stuff, proper shoes for hiking or hiking pants
>barely have enough money left for the train and ferry tickets to actually get to Yakushima from Tokyo
>fuck it, guess I'll wing it
>throw everything in a gym shoulder duffel bag type thing
>get my gym shoes, tshirt and swimming shorts because hey it's probably gonna get hot down there
>I'm ready to climb the summit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>next day go to train station and get a shinkansen ticket to Kagoshima, big coastal town from which ferries to Yakushima depart
>end up leaving the stupid folding bicycle at home because duffel bag is heavy enough as it is with all the instant risottos and gas canisters, can barely walk if I've got the folded bike in the other hand
>train trip to Kagoshima takes basically the whole day
>stay the night at a cheap Japanese inn type place, owned by a quirky Jap dude who's really into radios, first floor is basically his workshop with 1000s of radios and components
>next morning get myself a rice ball and little bottled green tea
>jump on the ferry to Yakushima
>on the Yakushima side there is an information office
>konnichiwa, I want to climb to the top of Yakushima
>cute staff lady looks a little concerned
>"here, please fill out this form indicating which day you plan to be at which camp sites and when you return let us know you're alive otherwise we have to send out a search party for you"
>don't worry I got this
>they give me some maps and tell me which bus to get on
>winding mountain road, 20 minutes to the trailhead
>everyone dressed pretty normal, no backpacks, don't know what oneesan was so worried about
>get off the bus and go through the entrance, start going up the trail
>spectacular scenery, every corner is teeming with life
>not even 10 minutes in and there are little deer crisscrossing the path
>butterflies the size of my hand
>deafening choruses of cicadas
>boulders covered by an inch of lush green moss that look like they would start moving any moment
>monkeys swinging through the canopy
>proper princess mononoke shit going on here
>also some massive hornets every now and then that scare the life out of me
>my exposed sweaty pasty gaijin legs are an object of intrigue to the insect life
>get to a rest site where families are chilling out, everyone having a good time
>spot a sign off to the side leading further into the mountain
>this must be my path

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>keep climbing on
>suddenly the path changes from nice sturdy wood planks to just dirt
>I'm seeing way fewer people now, only run into a person every 15 minutes or so
>the ones I run into are decked out in full gear, climbing sticks and bulging backpacks
>all those people on the bus were just here for a short day trip
>start getting thirsty, where's my water bottle
>realize I never actually brought one for the trip
>luckily never threw out the tea bottle I got for breakfast
>this 500ml ito en ocha bottle is the only thing I have to store water and it's empty
>start listening for rivers or waterfalls
>fortunately it rains a lot in Yakushima and I pass by quite a few mountain rivers/creeks
>path changes to railtracks, remnants from the old times when this island used to be logged
>nature start getting crazier, start seeing stumps with the width of a car that have had 3 or 4 new trees sprout on the sides and intertwine into a new tree on top of the stump shooting up into the sky
>start feeling delirious after hours of walking and lugging my duffle bag
>I'm convinced if I sit down for a minute I'll be absorbed into the moss or eaten by Shishigami forest deer god
>also have the strong urge to take a shit
>Yakushima is a protected nature reserve so the toilets up here are pit latrines that get cleaned out by volunteers
>some poor fucker has to hike up this way every month with a plastic barrel on their back to clean out all the shit
>the 2 toilets I've seen so far are literal hellholes into the abyss with a near constant stream of wasps and hornets funneling in and out, refuse to place my quivering gaijin butthole in their path and just keep holding it in
>as I ascend higher the streams become fewer and farther in between
>phone battery has died, no idea how long I've been going at this hike
>can barely see the sky through the canopy of coiled vines and towering cedars - but something tells me it's feeling a bit darker and colder than it should
>nightfall is coming

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>suddenly realize I'm not on a path anymore
>switching handling on my duffel bag for the millionth time trying to get a grip that's not awkward
>gym shoes are completely soaked since 6 hours ago
>swimming shorts offer a direct path for flying critters up to my nutsack
>thirsty, tired, really need to shit in this living breathing green hell
>kicking myself for not getting proper gear
>last human I passed was 2 hours ago
>and now there's no path, only a little colored ribbon tied to a tree
>spot another one 30 meters away
>climb over several boulders and sideways growing megavines
>see another ribbon tied to a branch
>keep following ribbons, no use looking at map anymore since I have 0 clue where I am
>thankfully I brought a flashlight and I will need it in about 5 minutes since the last slivers of light are quickly escaping this place
>turn the corner and come to face the biggest cedar tree in all of existence bursting from the earth surrounded by a matted terrace of roots
>jomon sugi, a 7000 year old cedar
>I know where I am now
>hear laughing voices in the distance
>start to run towards them as darkness envelops everything completely

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>close to the tree there is a little cinderblock hut for hikers
>fling open the door
>familiar face is looking back at me
>"..anon? what are you doing here"
>it's the manager of a guesthouse I lived in 3 years ago in Chiba
>remember he was an avid hiker and used to pin photos of his hikes to the community board
>tell him my story
>"hey I'm going to the summit tomorrow! why don't you join me?"
>finally, maybe this guy might help me to stay alive
>feeling good, cook up like 3 instant risottos
>realize I've boiled them together with the plastic condiment packets
>dont give a fuck, I'm tired and eat all that good shit up
>hands down best meal of my life
>go to bed, luckily I've brought a sleeping bag because it is now freezing cold
>cheese ravioli with roasted tomato sauce for breakfast
>ok I really need to shit now, this isn't funny
>check the toilet and it's just as bad as all the others, swear that something is slithering down there
>"anon are you ready? let's climb this bitch"
>y yeah let's do it
>fill up my tiny tea bottle
>buddy has camel water pack and a big 1L container
>struggling to keep up while sweating like a whito piggu, trying not to shit my pants
>my water runs out in 20 minutes
>at this altitude the earth is drier, no more creeks
>after an hour we reach another rest station with bigger hut, nobody there
>he's completely chill, doesn't even need to stop
>hey man why don't you go on ahead, I'll meet you at the summit
>"you sure? I can wait for you if you need to rest"
>nah nah I'm good, I'll catch up with you
>feel myself slipping out of consciousness as he walks off
>the second he turns the corner I waddle out to a clearing
>drop my swimming shorts
>an unbroken torrent of shit immediately bursts from my asshole as I grunt in pure extacy
>a nearby family of monkeys runs for their lives
>almost black out
>stand up and gaze upon my creation, kind of looks like mount fuji
>useless to try and cover it up, just leave it there

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>finally decide to give up my quest to the summit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>go back to the hut, as I'm walking I realize my coordination is way off

>nobody else is awake
>now multiple pitter patters, tiny legs drumming on the wooden floor boards and lots of them

>focus intensely at the now rising crescendo of almost rhythmic tiny thumping all around me

>spend the rest of the night terrified in a state of delirium

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
Dear /trv/eterans,

I have decided to create a thread for those interested in general information regarding living abroad. I think a lot of threads tend to discuss some singular aspects of living in certain countries, but I feel like regrouping these, no matter if they're country-specific or not, would be worth it, for the sake of archiving interesting information within one single (or a series of thread). This thread is aimed at prospecting beginners.

>Why should I live abroad ?
Many reasons. Cost of life can be better abroad, job opportunities more favorable to your field of work, a society you're more in tune with (safety, values). Other possibilities include doing an academic exchange or a double diploma, maybe an internship of some kind that will enhance your CV to prospective recruiters from your home country (or the one you want to go to.)

>But I don't want to live there forever !
It's fine, most people don't and leave after a few years. You don't have to marry a local, buy a house and stay there forever. Sometimes it's nice to go out there, take it out of your system, then come back all grown up and with some new tricks up your sleeve.

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
>What do you mean by that ? What do I gain from doing a temporary expatriation?
It really depends on how fruitful it was, but aside from whatever professional experience you've gain from it, by doing you so you have learned to leave your comfort zone, forced yourself into socializing with people who had no reason to talk to you besides speaking English and probably befriended some, negotiated for jobs and deals with people that are completely foreign to you and learned what it truly meant to be alone and be your own island, sometimes. If you came to say, Asia, with nothing more than a high school degree and nothing else but your hands, you've also learned how to network, find a job, and to pay your bills you actually had to learn how to keep that job. Of course, perhaps the conditions that made you get the job in the first place won't be there at home, which will make you stay. But at least you're actually functional now. And you'll be able to figure something out.

>Is immigration/expatriation something I should prepare ?
The more you prepare it, the better. Learning the local language (not necessarily bilingual but every bit helps), acquiring a skill, gathering information on how to get in and what visa schemes are available for you are all too important parts of a successful experience abroad.

>why the tripcode ?
Because I won't LARP. The answer you will receive from me will either be something I know to be true from personal experience. And the tripcode ensures that if I truly am bullshitting you, I can get called out for everything i've said throughout the series of threads that will be posted. It's a win-win.

And with that, the thread begins. If you're experienced, don't hesitate to share your experiences, tips and tricks you know. If you're not, don't hesitate to ask all the questions you want to ask.
P.S : human trafficking solliciters, remember that you're violating US law.

There are ways to do so, it depends on the region and what you are willing to do. In most cases, the answer is no. But in certain cases, Canada has signed WHV program with a certain number of countries. Meaning you can get a visa that allows you to work in the country for 6 months up to a year.

If your country is not part of this scheme, you should always check the canadien embassy's website regarding visas. As a rule, some special visas may apply to your specific country that I may not know of. If there aren't any, you can only get a work visa.

Alternatively, just look for a non-shitty job, or stay there for a short term, and meet people who can possibly hook you up with a visa

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
>>2390290
No problem. I'm only talking about Taiwan because that's what I know, and you seem to have either Taiwan or Japan as an endgoal. You won't solve being a shut-in by meeting up open people. You'll solve it by either meeting people who match your energy or truly learning why you can't socialize.

Introverts don't want to talk shop because they think small talk is a thing for retards, when really, small talk is the human way to show that they want to sniff your butt and enter your social circle so they can actually open up to you. Ironically, go really autistic and try to get into deep shit with them and they fucking freak out like anybody else because that's not what normally constituted people do, so damned if you do, and damned if you don't. Other things being invited to go have a meal with a group or with a friend and often refusing, which people understand as a rejection of friendship and not just a circumstantial thing, if repeated more than once.
It doesn't matter where you go, this is true everywhere.

>Are people open to be my friends ?
Since you said you were autistic, i'll tell you how it goes. In general, most people, Taiwanese included, are open to be your friend, provided you have some kind of pretext to meet them. If you don't know anybody, are not partaking in any hobbies and do not have a job yet, why would a perfect stranger befriend you ? Think about this problem, and trying to find some solutions on your own would be a good exercise.

Second, I always recommend people to go out and meet the expats in Taipei. They're a varied, decent bunch, very open, and are present in pretty much every night scene, they understand what it is to be a complete stranger to everyone and having to spontaneously meet new folks, and until you can understand how to make friends with locals, they can also introduce you to some. Internet people (not just 4chan) pretend they snob them but it's really that they've never talked to them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391118
>>2391118
People always say it's the best way but the way it happens makes it so that it basically never does. MNCs function in such a way that every national branch is its own company. They bill shit to each other, and either compete with, or work in fields that aren't quite the ones back home.

For example, a lot of MNCs will have folks working sales abroad to sell the products produced back home. And the people they will hire are obviously locals because they might be cheaper or just more at ease with communicating with the locals. Also, hiring an equivalent foreign worker is pound to pound as skilled as a local is considered bad practice and is starting to get heavily curbed in Asia.

Therefore, differentiation is key. Differentiation through diplomas (Prestigious ones), differentiation through specialization (PhDs in certain fields of expertise that are needed there, for example, or at least +5 year in a field but more is better).

If you're ballsy enough you can point out a certain need in a foreign branch, explain how to fill it so they can tailor a job offer for you there, too.
This being said, a lot of people manage to get to work abroad if they have +5 years exp in dev, sometimes less. Foreign internships, exchanges and double diplomas during your studies can help if you take the necessary steps professionally to make it work.

In a nutshell, anything that makes you a better person than a local works. And that also goes by evening the playing fields. Some countries have visa schemes that facilitate foreign hiring for skilled workers. Speaking the local language in a professional capacity also helps leveling the playing field and beating other foreign contenders. Again, you don't necessarily need to do all that to try your luck. But I suggest you orient yourself by tailoring yourself to be a competitive foreign worker as you go, which will only better your odds. Also, seriously, the field. Don't go to china with a pol sci degree.

You could possibly stay more to maximize your chances and enlarge the window of opportunities. Of course, don't just go there without any clue. Apply for job offers, make sure you mention that you will be available for an interview during said time period, and see what gives. No need to go for a month if you've only got one offer.

I believe in the material, meat and potatoes. I am interested in the things that I know will bring me happiness. Call me a hedonist if you want, but I refuse to do things that will, further down the line, only bring me depression, contempt for other people, and spend my precious life on this earth.
If there is a more gratifying job, a better partner to be with, a better place to be in, i'll go right there and I see no reason to deprive myself of anything that could be a step up. An argument can be made about what makes it truly a step-up, sure, but it is undeniable that for some people in certain countries, you can really improve your life by going abroad. I actually believe that a temporary experience (which is what an expatriation is, by the way) is nice to have. Discovering foreign cultures in an in-depth way is a life-changing experience and it doesn't have to be a permanent one.

Also, just because you have less value in your country doesn't mean that this value is inherent to you. Maybe being an introverted engineer in a western country that has abandoned its industrial sector translates to being a polite, at ease socially engineer in Taiwan's booming industry ? Maybe being a French chef in France is hardly well paid and recognized because we've got so many of them, but it translates to being a great chef abroad with very interesting and classy recipes ?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395192
>I thought increasingly in asia you require a degree level in whatever to qualify for English teaching at least I thought that was the case in China and Japan.
That is increasingly, and indeed, nearly always the case, and not just in China and Japan. Thailand requires degrees too, has done for years now.

People without degrees but with certifications can still sometimes find work in Thailand, typically either as private tutors or at the sleaziest of private language school sweatshops, but they can’t get work permits or non-immigrant visa sponsorship. So the work (and as often as not, the teachers’ residence) is under the table and officially illegal, with all the risk that implies. It’s been a few years since the last crackdown, but Thai authorities have caught and mass deported English teachers working without proper papers several times that I can remember.

The only place I’ve ever personally known someone to work full-time as a teacher without a degree was Cambodia, but there may be other Wild West possibilities out there.

Still almost certain to run into visa/permit problems, though.

posts.com: how do you find a job abroad? im a young engineer and id like to work in asia for a few years, im a bit clueless on how to find a job postings. i just tried linked in and some googling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395792
Linkedin, indeed. Check on the internet where do people post their job postings for a particular country. Get yourself some letters of recommendation. References are also ok but since some employers might not care since they can't really believe them, having some letters right off the bat can be a plus for these cases.
Possibly translate your CV.

If a country seriously strikes your fancy, you could try to go there for a week or two with the sole goal of networking. Meet literally anyone with the largest common denominator, aka alumnis, then dudes in your field you might meet in expat bars that are from your home country, and just ask around for pointers and tips (never directly for a job). Also, read up on this process of networking so you don't sound like a scummy hustler.


Add a lot of recruiters on linkedin from the particular country in the companies that interest you.

If you can arrange some interviews before your trip do so and make sure you specify the time period at which you will be present.

Finally, one of the bigger reason people struggle is because they either do not have enough experience , or they're not specialists in a field the local job market is interested in.

If all you do is sit down in the comfort of your home and job and apply for job postings abroad with a foreign address, unwilling to do your interviews physically, with little to no investment in staying by forcing into others the fact that you speak english and the unwillingness of doing nothing else, there is literally no reason why they should hire you.
Not only sponsoring a visa can be a pain in the ass to the HR, you going there and realizing you didn't like the place and leaving after a year makes it so not worth it for them to even consider you.

You should also compensate for the difficulty of the endeavor with a good enough volume. If you're looking to go to Taiwan, do them all-Taiwan, Japan, Korea, China, HK and Singapore. Even the ones you don't want -who cares ? My friend who was in a situation similar to yours, applied to around 500 offers over the course of a year and got around 5 interviews, 2 of which resulted in a "yes".

Another had literally no fucking experience whatsoever but just happened to save some money and went on a 2 month trip in Taiwan after college to celebrate. My man had a job lined up by the end of the first month. That guy was smart however, had the great idea of hiring a professional translator to rigorously translate his CV and cover letter, and the guy just played up to the HRs.

As for me, the reason why i'm here is because i've literally tailored my studies to finding a job there.Double diplomas, internships... There's a lot of things you can do to get yourself wherever you want provided you think about it soon enough.

This dude right here.
That's how you do solo traveling.
Why the FUCK do you *need* to interact with other people? You come to the hostel, talk to the receptionist for 5 minutes to pay, get your room assigned and find out the internet password.
After that why would you even bother with other people? You come in, put on a more or less acceptable smile and just say "Hi", then proceed with your business.

I did need to ask around for help during my first trips, after getting some milleage I just learned to figure everything out myself, even when I fail to figure it out/fuck up and end up getting lost or something I just keep walking until I find my way and it all just adds to the experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Raw egg would be the hardest to avoid.
Many dishes and desserts are based on raw eggs, e.g. carbonara and tiramisu, mousse etc.
A lot of roux and “white sauces” have eggs thrown into it and are partially cooked; it definitely got stirred into the warm sauce so it may be considered as partially cooked. It really depends on how severe is your allergy towards semi-raw eggs.
As for desserts, get anything more custard-based as it’s at least cooked.

Peanuts are easy to avoid in Italy, I do not remember any meals using these; it’s usually walnut or hazelnut that are both grown in Italy. Just be wary of Chinese and Vietnamese restaurants, they love peanuts and they put it in everywhere.

In some European countries, many restaurants don’t take allergies seriously, like in France. Not sure about Italy because I don’t have major food allergies.
