posts.com:
>>2396592
1/2
Been several times, most recently in 2018 and summer 2022. Great city and quite cheap overall, here are some basic recommendations if you have a couple of days:

-Buda Castle, free and provides nice views of the city. You can often see the ceremonial Horse Guards do their rounds, which is fun. There is also a museum of Hungarian art within the castle grounds which is quite cheap and well worth seeing.
-Thermal Baths: if you can only do one, do Széchenyi. Its the biggest and has a nice variety of hot pools, cold/medium pools and sauna/steam rooms. When you arrive, don't get confused and think that its only an outdoor pool- you have to go indoors and look around to find all the pools. If you have time to do two, do Gellert as well, it is smaller but less crowded and in a prettier setting.
-Ruin Bars: there are several, the most famous is Szimpla, which will pretty much always be busy during drinking hours. Stroll around its area and you'll find others each with their own quirks, as well as a kind of Hungarian food court/area that tends to be around there.
-Orsokahz: Hungarian parliament, a really magnificent building. Even if you aren't interested in architecture or history this is well worth checking out, it dominates the skyline of the city and is just breathtakingly beautiful and magnificient, especially as you cross into the city at night and see it for the first time. You can only go in with a guided crowd tour, but its worth doing. Slightly expensive by Hungarian standards but not too bad, but be sure to book well in advance because English tours fill up.

Whatever you do, be sure to walk the banks of the Danube by Parliament and cross the Chain Bridge and Princess Margaret Bridge.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2396592
>>2396840
2/2

Other good stuff:

-Go the the Zwach distillery and get a tour, its cheap and they can get you pretty hammered if your guide is feeling like it. Zwach is also a very uniquely Hungarian beverage and there's rarely even anyone at the distillery. Fair warning: most people find regular Zwach pretty fucking foul, but the plum and coffee varieties are good shit. On the topic of food and drink, be sure to try the following: Tokay, which is Hungarian sweet wine, Langos fried flatbreads with toppings (go to Retro Langos for these), goulash, and Palinka (pear brandy which I personally think is foul but they like it).
-Gul Baba street, one of the steepest streets in major European cities, which ends with the tomb of an old Muslim theologian/scholar, also a pilgrimage site and rose garden.
-Citadela, where you'll see the big soviet statue, old fort that has the best views of the city and a nice hike to get up there
-Margaret Island, which is a cool island in the Danube with gardens and an assortment of stuff, good spot for picnics
-Fisherman's Bastion, which are the white fortifications you'll see, you can enter for free and if a turret/tower tries to charge for entry you can generally just come back at sundown and they won't be charging any more.

I think you can get to Bratislava by boat very easily from Budapest, but I've never been.
Don't take taxis, they are a literal cartel designed to scam people.
Also get some turkish food while you are there and use trams instead of the subway. The trams are great, run everywhere and are cheap, the subway fucking sucks, everything is ancient and last time I took it a train caught fire. Anyway I fucking love Budapest, I wish the Hungarian government could pay me to shill it on Tanzanian Hand-Looming Forums.

>>2396840
>>2396848
I'm an expat living in Hungary, and while I don't particularly care for Budapest or the people in it, I do support people coming here and spending money. So, I offer a few corrections/elaborations--

>Ruin Bars ... Szimpla ... Hungarian food court/area
Szimpla is the most famous. It's going to be full or tourists, but I can imagine it's fun for young people. The "food court" is called "Street Food Karavan"-- it's at the end of the street that Szimpla is on. If you're at one end of the block, and there's no food court, it's on the other end. From Szimpla, if you keep going in the same direction, then turn left when the road ends, you'll pass by a nice brunch place called Cirkusz that is sadly crowded all the time, and then if you turn right you'll end up a Gozsdu udvar, which could also be described as a kind of food court area. If you put the names into a search engine, you should be able to see the locations.
>Orsokahz
Orszaghaz. Book the tour online and print out the tickets. I've heard it's great. If you're there, you might as well walk across Szabadsag ter. Check out the monument to the Soviet liberators of Budapest, the statues of Reagan and H.W. Bush, the old stock exchange (on your right), and the fortress-like US embassy (on your left). At the opposite end of the square, there's a memorial to the German occupation of Hungary. You can then continue ~200 meters along Oktober 6 street, pass by George Soros's university, and you'll soon be able to see the square in front of Saint Steven's Basilica. The basilica is pretty cool, but it's expensive to tour. There are a bunch of tourist trap restaurants in that area, but, if you're there around lunch time, I recommend hummusbar on Oktober 6.
>Zwach
Zwack is the distillery. The beverage is called Unicum. I don't drink it, but the closest commonly known drink similar to it would be Jaegermeister.
>Palinka
Palinka can be made from many fruits. It can vary in strength from ~20% to ~80%.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you want beaches, south East QLD. Stay on the southern end of the Gold Coast (ideally south of Burleigh Heads). You can cross the border into NSW which has some of the best rated beaches in the country at Cabarita and Pottsville.

If you want city vibes, go to Melbourne.

If you want a variety of landscapes, go to Tasmania. Most of our mainland has beautiful but samey landscapes for hours on end, whereas Tassy you can see a variety within a few hours drive.

Avoid Sydney. Maybe a day or two to see the famous Harbourside shit, but it is a soulless bugman city. The conservative state government has squeezed any life out of it over the years, there's fuck all to do there now except gamble your pay away and buy overpriced shit. Everything Sydney can offer a tourist is done 4x better by the 3 places I've mentioned.

Personally if I had to spend 2 weeks here I'd spend 8 days touring Tasmania in a van and the rest chilling in Burleigh Heads or Coolangatta on the Gold Coast.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2384843
>Would you recommend visiting Adelaide?
Adelaide has fantastic food, an actual nightlife district (Hindley/Rundle St, but their sidestreets are where the real fun is, with heaps of fantastic cocktail bars, especially Peel St & Leigh St), and is very easy to commute around, along with being far cheaper than Melbourne and Sydney.
As far as beaches go, Adelaide has a lot of nice ones, though if you prefer warmer water and more of a beachside culture, then you'd want Queensland.
If you're coming to Adelaide, there's also a fair few worldclass wineries less than a half hour out of the CBD, and a great deal of great distilleries and breweries. If you're not a drinker, there's fantastic walking trails through the parklands and the Adelaide Hills. It's pretty easy to get to nature from Adelaide too.

Any reason why only 2 weeks?

Like other anons said; must do's:
>Melbourne for nightlife, food, culture/city/architecture - Great Ocean road is awesome too
>Gold Coast for beaches, hinterland, party-esque vibe
>Cairns (Port Douglas) for scenery, snorkelling, wildlife/rainforest, good backpacking scene
That's pretty much your two weeks.

>Tasmania if you have time and want a quieter/more NZ vibe with mountains/unique coastlines
>WA has awesome reefs/beaches but it's to far away from everything else to justify in such a short trip.
>Adelaide for wineries, but same sort of experience can be done at the Victorian peninsulas/Yarra Valley.
>Sydney is pretty meh but go for a day or two if you want to check out Manly/Bondi and the harbour. Blue Mountains is cool, but can do Grampians in Victoria instead too.

100% There's some nice beaches and shit but it is just a mini-America and an overpriced and less exciting one at that.
>>2383802
>Is it really so bad that I should never visit?
Wait until you're an old dude and come to Australia on one of those guided boomer trips and see the national parks and wildlife and crap. Otherwise it's mostly just a few overpriced, overcrowded touristy places that at the end of the day aren't all that exciting. Sure there are beautiful beaches here but you also have that in SEA. Plus in Asia you have a totally different culture, vibe, food, interesting and even confronting experiences and loads more fun. Also much better value for money overall.
>What exactly is it that makes Thailand better?
Warm all year round, nice beaches, great food, loads of interesting and beautiful places to visit, close and easy to get to other Asian countries, like Cambodia (picrel), vastly different and interesting culture, place of contrasting cultures and attitudes, more dynamic and vibrant, cheaper alcohol, cheaper accomodation, transport etc.
>Are you just talking about sex?
No.There is loads to do in Thailand and Asia apart from sex. You can easily spend a month there, have a lot of fun and not have sex.

He had a great run, though, and I hope he enjoyed at least some of it a lot.

Bourdain in the day like said >>2384987
At the time he first broke he was a breath of fresh air.
He visited a lot of countries not really on mainstream radar.

Mid way through his career it became obvious the grungey rocker late 90’s-2000 persona he had had fizzled away leaving that kind of ‘I was cool once’ old dude sycophant in its place.
Just as countries like Cambodia had changed in big business corporate behemoths, so had Bourdain.

By the end he was a limp, whiny, pushy and opinionated, shell of his former self who would’ve disgusted the younger Bourdain who started this journey.

The truth is much like a country like Cambodia- he aged wrong. The direction he went in as a corporate spokesmen for CNN, hedonism and politics (yuck!) could only lead to a hollowing out of himself.

If he’d been more selective as he got older of the types of journey he’d undertake and share, and dive deeper into very selective niche type of travel he could’ve been a true legend of the travel writing/journal genre, but he sold out and will only ever be a contender in history.

It’s all about how people age…
It’s genuinely disappointing, as he could’ve been probably the only person in his old age in the early 21st century who could’ve documented living in a Shinto temple for a month, before living with Aleut eating seals, then joining isis over a mint tea. He literally had the opportunity to do anything in the world and yet chose to be a company man.

That’s why he was stupid.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395382
Been there last year, I will summarize:

Tolls EVERYWHERE, factor that into travel costs, probably paying about 10 euro every 100 km.
Look for quieter spots that dont have tons of "foreign" tourists, my personal favourite was Kamena Vourla - it was mostly greeks on domestic holidays. Second favourite was Mytikas because it was much quieter than others.
Many of the roads and streets are poor and the drivers are crazy so always keep it in the back of your head to be careful.
Snacks are expensive, you want a bottle of coke? Some places sell 500ml cokes for 3 euro.
There are quite varying temperatures across the country, next to the ocean is generally cooler but in the midlands it can be agonizingly hot.
If driving, make sure to visit petrol stations often, lots of them close on a Sunday too so don't get stuck!
The Greeks are very kind (when they are not driving) and will talk to you if they can, some even took us home and were very hospitable.
Pay attention to google maps - if you are sure you have the right place but the journey says it takes a crazy long time, there is likely a valid reason (landslides etc).
A lot of places do not let you put normal toilet roll in the toilet - I wish I was kidding but they expect you to shit, wipe, and put your shitty wipes in the bin next to the toilet. This was honestly the most disgusting thing about Greece, I didn't even see one bidet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395382
Get bougatsa for breakfast

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395382
• Greek food is the best, focus on grilled meat, fish
• Try desserts: galatopita, bougatsa, galaktoboureko
• Greek fast food is patrician. It's hard for foreign fast food companies to get a foothold because local fast food is so good. The go-to is Gyro or meaet skewers(kalamaki).
• They got some bomb ass sour cherry drinks and sodas. Try the sour cherry one from Loux, amazing.
• Try feta from a barrel. The Olympos one from a grocery store is good.
• In Athens there are a lot of amazing eateries at all price ranges.
• Avoid tourist traps and people who holler at you to sit in their place.
• Unlike spain that barely has 30-50% (depending on area) of households with air conditioning, Greece has 99%. Who's the third country now?
• Greece is a bit far behind technologically and many roads are completely shit. It's not great for shopping either. Around Athens' Kolonaki there are some shops though like Balenciaga and high-end watches boutiques. You won't find Uniqlo though.
• Greeks are super nice
• Some Greeks have inferiority complex and are whiny bitches. The lowest class ones are nearer middle-eastern in their behavior instead of more north/western. Kefalonia and islands around the Ionian sea are colored by Italian heritage and genetics. They were never controlled by the Ottomans either. Completely different from the Cyrpean mutts or people from south Aegean islands.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2396973
cont.
• There is a lot of hidden wealth in Greece that is related to maritime shipping. Unbeknownst to many that aren't familiar with the sector, Greece boasts the largest fleet in terms of capacity, mogging even China and Japan.
• These people usually have residences around the Attica region, summer house(s) on islands, yatch(s), residences in US east coast, UK, southern france, Switzerland. You won't meet these people though since they're very insulated.
• Greek women aren't that great imho. I don't know what it is but they just don't do it for me.
• Kamena Vourla as the anon mentioned is good. Crete is large and has tons to explore. You'll probably need years to figure it out. The culture in Crete also is a bit different. People there are a bit tougher and there's a Vendetta culture going on reminiscent of Italy. Often you'll see signage that has holes in it because of a shoot-out. They might be a bit taller and have blue eyes. Different phenotype.
• Athens is basically many generations of different socio-economic backgrounds stacked on top of each other so there are stark differences of income. Someone who works in the shipping industry and does well might make north of 200k USD while an average person might struggle to get by with 800USD a month working at a grocery store clerk and never getting enough money to move out of the family home.
• Distances in Athens can be quite large and the center is living hell during summer because of all the concrete that makes it like an over. During June-August, try to avoid Athens or keep it short or do activities after the sun sets.
• Transport is not that good in Athens, just use Uber.

Canada’s historical mistreatment of its First Nations citizens is on display for the world to see. While the nation had reached some accommodations with the various tribes, it’s still very clear that the First Nations people are viewed as being second class citizens in many areas of Canada, particularly in areas with large populations of tribal members. The poor state of infrastructure on many of the reserves also clearly indicate that the government’s priority is not the residents of those areas.

As far as Blacks: While Canada was never as racist as the Deep South of the United States, segregation (de jure and de facto) were very common in Canada until the 1960s. Black Canadians who descended from either people brought over as slaves, former sea farers and escaped American slaves, lived in segregated areas, faced discrimination for jobs and financing and were often harassed by law enforcement and White Canadians. While this changed drastically in the last 50 years ( due in part to changes in the US and an influx of Afro-Carribbeans and African immigrants and refugees) , racism is not uncommon in areas of Canada which have small non-White populations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393549
Asians - Both East and South Asians have experienced a great deal of discrimination in Canada, although the fact that many came to Canada with wealth or were able to move into the middle and upper classes within a generation or so seems to have tempered this somewhat. Just as in the United States, most Asians and their descendants live in and around the major cities and urban areas, so the prejudice that they experience isn’t as widespread as the prejudice against Blacks and First Nations people seems to be. It does , however exists as referenced below.

Latinos - The recent influx of Latinos into the country seems to have provoked some prejudice against. However, Canada’s Latino population is relatively small, most confined to the cities, and it really hasn’t integrated into the mainstream. As climate change worsens and it becomes clear that Canada can support many more people than its harsh winters currently allows, there are likely to be more immigrations from Latino majority nations which are likely to face the need to flee that change. If history is any indicator if/when their numbers increase, so will the prejudice and discrimination that they face.

Canada is not a bad country, and its racism isn’t as profound as it is in many areas of the United States. It’s not “turning racist.” It IS racist, but it is also slightly less so than many other countries in the Western world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393733
Was just in Zagreb two months ago. Extremely comfy city, but was very cold though when I was there. Stay near Jelacic Square, its the center of the city and very cool. The whole city reminds me a lot of the atmosphere of Vampire The Masquerade Bloodlines, has a very gothic and "Dracula" like feel to it, especially in the dark winters and nightime. Eat at and support the old school mom and pop family restaurants where everything tastes home-cooked in large portions, avoid the shitty trend of cringy, wannabe "Instagram" restaurants that place more emphasis on "presentation" than on the food- my filter is if they serve food on a square plate then its going to be absolute trash. The restaurants I liked to eat at were Croation barbeque restaurants known as "Konobas" which are the main local staples of their food. Any place that serves a "Mixed Meat Plate" (which is fucking amazing), Sopska salad (also amazing) and Ajvar sauce (also amazing) is going to be legit. You probably already know this though if you are coming from Slovenia, because its generally the same all over the Balkans. Have fun, I wish I had more time in Zagreb myself, I was only there for 3 days.

posts.com:
Hey OP, am also half and half

I was making 200-400rmb an hour in Beijing 2015-2017 as a full-time student. However that was mainly through private lessons, working under the table at a tutoring center, etc..

Basically I'd get a part-time job, work at it for a bit, guanxi with parents, and cut out the middleman. Turn those 150/hr tutoring jobs into 300. Parents and students were fine with my 'racial ambiguity'.

The only time I felt slighted was getting hired for a high school speech course. The pay was good at 500rmb/hr pathed up to a work visa, and too good to be true. Right as classes started the coordinator dropped me from 5 classes to 1 and told me I'd be a substitute teacher. They told me I shouldn't have gotten the job on paper (Chinese last name) but was handsome enough to make it work. Some jobs aren't worth taking

I don't know how flexible the situation is with Student Visa's nowadays but basically everyone I knew who studied hard in China was working on the side. I knew this Bangladeshi guy with a London accent who taught over Wechat. 2 hours a night at 300rmb/hr teaching people barely able to string a sentence together.

At one point I also did apply for a formal workvisa / classroom monkey job, but you have to fight for every bit and piece of your contract. It's always a headache with contracts.

Already spending too much time on this OP, but tldr Parents and Students like mixed-race, schools and companies will use it to bargain against you.

Anyway that's my experiences OP, best of luck

>>2391474 (OP)
Moroccanfag here.
Morocco, and muslim countries in general, tend to give foreigners a lot of leeway because they understand the culture is different. They have millions of tourists coming every year, especially during the summer, and the ties with france and spain are particularly strong, historically, diplomatically and culturally too. The only thing they're not okay with is what they perceive to be obvious marks of disrespect. No faux pas will actually be taken personally by most locals. Morocco is the most liberal arab country there is.

In terms of public displays of affection, everything short of kissing is fine. You can hug your gf, hold her hands, etc. It's ok to talk to women, and since you're with your gf i'm guessing you're not going to be flirting anyway so it should be fine. To be perfectly honest, if you kissed, there wouldn't be a lynching either. A local would just call you out and that's it.

>what small things that aren't a big deal for us are frowned upon?
pretty much nothing. Except maybe one : there are liquor stores all over the place, and they usually sell you stuff in black bags or shit like that. Don't show alcohol on you. Also, a big hallmark of a tourist restaurant with high markups is that they sell alcohol. If a restaurant sells alcohol, i guarantee you'll see only foreigners in there.

BTW, don't have any pity towards the panhandlers, especially the pushy ones or the kids. They earn a lot of fucking money while the guys doing the real jobs don't get none and then they take that money to their parents who are basically pimping them out. Please don't perpetuate this.

Where was the best place you travelled to that had the best fruit - quality, availability, presence of wild fruit, etc?
Obviously the tropics are gonna come out on top here but I'm hoping anons can narrow it down to some region or place that struck them as a cut above the rest. Whether it was wild fruit from foraging or markets in a city with outstanding produce, I'd like to hear your stories.

I haven't been outside Europe so the one place that stood out to me was Uppsala in Sweden - Mulberry, Plum & Cherry trees growing everywhere. In late July & August you can literally eat for free

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Undoubtedly Morocco. As poor as the people are there, I don’t think they realize they have better access to fresh, seasonable produce than most westerners. Last time I was there you could get half a kilo of tangerines for 20¢ and they were always peak ripeness, not hit-and-miss like supermarket citrus. Pomegranates, cherries, all for almost free. A street food specialty in the north are these weird berries called chachnou I’ve never seen anywhere else. In the south it’s prickly pears, which they’ll peel for you so you don’t suffer. The fact that you find all this stuff by wandering through medieval souks is icing on the cake.
For wild foraging, Oahu was good. Lychees fucking everywhere and I found a few weird tropical things including mountain apples and something native to the Philippines which tasted like a strawberry smoothie.
Maine is a paradise for wild blueberries. There’s probably no fruit that even comes close in flavor IMO. You’re allowed to pick them in Acadia NP though unfortunately they ripen at peak tourist season.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The single best mangoes I have ever tasted, by an order of magnitude, were a variety indigenous to and grown almost exclusively in Haiti. There’s a Dominican cousin that gets exported but it’s inferior. Costa Rica had and Hawaii tied for the finest papaya I’ve ever had—a smaller, lighter-fleshed, less mealy variety than the standard squashlike mush. Thailand is an all-round champ for tropical fruits apart from the aforementioned, but it’s not a great place for wild fruit foraging. In-season cherries from the Pacific Northwest or British Columbia are hard to beat.

>>2367756
There's not much to tell. Probably a meme story on /trv. I went through a long list of terrible life events, both by my own fault and out of my control. Hated my job and considered quitting but I was terminated before I had the chance. I had severance pay and nothing else going for me. My apartment lease was up and I moved my stuff to storage, decided to go to Japan for a few months and maybe end it afterwards or along the way. Once in Japan, I spent a week or two adjusting, and I realized that having daily challenges in life made existential problems go on the back burner.
Met a girl on Tinder while it still was a "friend finder" in Asia. Used her as a tour guide and went to a love hotel a few times. It was casual and I met another girl, who was clingy and (I soon discovered) crazy. Met another. Made friends with Japanese guys and girls (and some expats) and developed a social circle - which didn't last longer than my trip, but amazed me by how easy it was when I wasn't wrapped up in my own head.
Decided that life really wasn't so bad, at least as long as it stayed interesting. And decided not to kill myself and instead looked for ways to earn a living remotely. Applied for jobs until I got one.
In my opinion, the destination I chose was irrelevant. I'd often thought to myself "before I kill myself, I'll go to X country/location". They've varied over the years: California, Africa, India, Japan. When it was time, my destination was Japan. I guess I didn't really want to die because instead of taking the quick jump off an expressway bridge, I actually visited the destination I'd dreamed about. I'm glad I did, and now many years later, I've got kids and I'm happier than I've ever been before. Happier than many of my old friends back in my home country. I wouldn't change a thing.

Lofoten, Norway
> A string of craggy peaks in the high Arctic. the Gulf Stream means the winters aren't that bad and the summers, with 24/7 daylight, are unbelievable. >>2367779
>It amazed me how easy it was when I wasn't wrapped up in my own head

This is exactly why I urge people to go backpacking. When you spend a couple weeks (or months, or years) doing the backpacking thing, every day offers something new and you get a new perspective on your problems. I can't explain why, maybe it's because when you're backpacking you tend to make last minute decisions ("Fuck it, I'll skip Nice and take the train to Marseille!") and that makes you realise that you can make decisions about the more important things in your life too.
There is a phenomenon that astronauts come back to Earth with a greater interest in environmental concerns, altruism etc. Because seeing the whole world as just a ball of blue and green has some crazy effects on their beliefs. I think backpacking is kind of similar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Favorite:
>Chhattisgarh, India: rural and predominately tribal state in east-central India. The whole area has a bad reputation for insurgency and violence, which keeps most visitors away. However, the entire region is incredibly beautiful, insofar it's heavily forested, mountainous, and incredibly biodiverse. It also has some of the most unique and isolated cultures in the entirety of "mainland" India. People are very, very friendly, but not in the obnoxious, quasi-autistic way that North Indians can be friendly. Locals can be a little suspicious of outsiders, but there's zero hassle or harassment. The tribals also make really good alcohol, kek
>Turkey: First country I ever visited outside of the United States. I went for the first time in 2013 and stayed in Istanbul for about a year in 2020-2021. IMO, it's one of the most-visited countries in the world for a reason: the people are extraordinarily hospitable, especially outside of big cities, and the entire country is drop-dead gorgeous. Istanbul is probably--and unironically--one of the most naturally beautiful urban areas in the world. Great views everywhere, reasonably safe, and cheap AF due to the ongoing lira crisis
>Colombia + Mexico: hard tie, can't really pick which I prefer. I'm not a coomer, I just really liked the sort of energy and vibrancy in most big, Latin American cities. If I had to choose one of the two, I'd probably go with Mexico, just because the food is so much better

picrel from a bike trip I took in east-central india earlier this year (sorry for crappy angle, don't have anything better on laptop and too lazy to transfer from phone)

>Athens

The center of Athens has been taken over by immigrants, mostly shitty Pakistanis and Bangladeshis. Greeks have fled the center of Athens to further away exurbs like Korydallos, Marousi, Kifissia, Lagonisi, Gylfada, etc.

In Athens the opposite of what is happening in most of the world is happening. Most the world has seen the city center being reclaimed by the rich and the professional yuppie class and their gentrifying, but in Athens the property market is the reverse, the city center is now a dump that is like an Islamic shitstain country and the outer areas of Athens are more expensive and sought after.

Finally this trip I spent much more time in the wealthier sections on the outer perimeter of Athens and the infrastructure still sucks, but it is nothing like the dystopia that is the Athens city center which is a mini Karachi or Dhaka at this point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2373726
Btw, I don't want to screw anyone over with this post:

I am not saying or recommending to stay at those exburbs which are further away from almost all the tourist destinations you will want to visit. They are also further from the cultural events if you know Greek.

If you have more money it is probably better to stay in Monastiraki or Plaka that are in the city center but still too expensive for the Islamic riff raff to swarm on the property market. If you have less money it is probably better to stay in Exarcheia which is much cheaper, but poor Greek hippies, arthouse types, anarchists and communists still live there which limits the Islamic floodgate.

I personally have chosen a hotel in the center of Pakistan in Greece, Metaxourgeio. But I know Greek and much more interested in participating in Greek language nightlife(theater, concerts, etc.) and the city center is still closer where most of those venues are located. The nearby subway also has just a few stops till it connects to Trainose(suburban rail line), Omonia, Syntagma, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
best
South Lake Tahoe. It's the most gorgeous place Ive ever seen. The lake is insane. Awesome outdoor bars. Amazing bike trails and hikes. But it still has a downtown area with a lot of good food and bars. Sitting around at the Hangar bar drinking beer by the fire at night under the stars is a vibe that's hard to match.

Jackson Hole Wyoming. The food is shockingly good. Every place in town is like a gourmet cowboy bar. You can do pretty much any outdoor outdoor activity. Whitewater rafting the snake river was one of the best experiences of my life. 3 days in Jackson Hole was not enough.

Maui. The best beaches Ive ever seen were in Makena on Maui. We found a condo for $300/night and that was a really good deal. I bought fresh fish a couple times and just grilled out to cut down on the outrageous restaurant bills we racked up. It's insanely expensive and we probably spent 4 grand on a 6 day trip for the 2 of us, but I felt like it was money well spent.

Worst
Portland Oregon. The memes are true. Portland is a homeless cesspool. There were homeless people camped out front of our Airbnb on a normal suburban street. It was one of the least charming cities Ive ever visited.

Atlantic City New Jersey. We parked the car and someone tried to sell us crack within 30 seconds. It's like vegas with none of the attractions but in the worst neighborhood you've ever seen.

Fresno California. You'll probably never go there, because why would you? I had to stay there for a conference. Your nightly choice of dining options are Dominoes Pizza, and a 24 hour McDonalds. It actually has worse crime than LA.There is literally NOTHING to do.

I’ve been to about 80 countries and I don’t think I genuinely hated any. Yeah there are up and downs but I have always found pleasant surprises. Some countries are better than others, for sure. Then there are countries I won’t really come back because I think I did most of it (tiny little ones).

Countries I liked the most:
- Paraguay: the memories of camping and herding cows with Paraguayan equivalent of gauchos in Chaco when I was kid still haunt me to this day.

- Iceland: did a multi-days trek in the middle of nowhere, in snowy volcanic landscape. Nothing is remotely similar.

- Extremadura in Spain, Yunnan in China in the early 00s, Chile, Lake Tahoe in Burgerland, some swampy place in Skåne Sweden (pic rel) etc. Too many things to list.

My latest trip was a road-trip in Netherlands. I liked it, I learned and saw a lot.
I love traveling so much bros.

>what has changed since 2019?
Forgot to answer this part. First in 2012, then far more substantially in 2019, the Chinese Communist Party forced the Hong Kong government to rewrite large parts of its legal framework (which was supposed to remain untouched until 2047) to align with Chinese law instead of the old British common law. Among other things, HK defendants can now be tried in Mainland China if the CCP demands it. It also purged the HK legislature of anyone who wasn’t fully sympathetic to the CCP.
>I thought they were dropping most of the covid regulations
Nope, just the mandatory quarantine period. Masks are still mandatory, even outside, and they still have a digital vaccine passport system in place with no end date in sight.

posts.name: Anonymous

Best

>Lucerne, Switzerland.
Fucking awesome place, and a great middle ground between alpine city and country. Everything is gorgeous and the kapellbrucke is stellar, but the biggest problem is that everything is fucking expensive as shit, making you feel like a pauper next to all the wealth. My favorite place in the whole world.

>Bend, Oregon.
It's in a very tenuous place as people are beginning to discover it en-masse, but it's a pleasure to visit. Lots of places to go outdoors, lively town, and a young populace. Again, the problem is that granolas and remote techfags are flocking to it, so the future doesn't look so good. Also has the last Blockbuster in the world, which is neat.

>Molde, Norway.
I'm a bit biased because I have family here, but it's a cute town on the waterfront with lots of verticality. Easy to get to the countryside, and the atlantic road isn't far. Just a very pleasant place that follows the beat of its own drum. I'd visit another larger town as a tourist, however.

Turns out my favorite places are all mountainous and expensive. Go figure.

Worst

>San Francisco, California
The biggest tumor of a city I can think of. This is what happens when you have an idyllic region grow for too long, it begins to rot from the inside out. Worse yet, the tumor has metastasized and is starting to infect surrounding regions as well. Fuck this place.

>Milan, Italy
Dirty, expensive, and a worse italian version of Paris. Hosts a bunch of lazy migrants and faux posh italians who think they're above everyone else. The only nice parts are the duomo and last supper mural, and you can see those within a day. Go to Como or Lugano instead, those are FAR superior to this shithole.

>Aberdeen, Washington
No wonder Kurt sang into his shotgun, I would want to die if I had to live in this depressing hellhole too. So desolate and dreary on this part of the coast, and there's plenty of other A-tier places you can go instead if you want to see PNW nature.

My experience is not so wide as some anonii here , but here's mine:

Best:
>Budapest
due to shitty government and inflation, really cheap local restaurants and hotels for other europeans. Nice club scene. Clean enough. Nice views, places to see.

>Berlin
Outstanding nightclubs, some say best in Europe, art, (Turkish kebabs...), culture, liked the overall feel.

> Rome
Walking on history. Been there few times, still lots to see. Cheap af quality red wine. Art, culture etc.

Favourable Mentions:
>Heidelberg, germany
what a nice town between mountains, university town, not too big, nightlife and things to do for a couple days
>Turku, Finland
The town is not big or extremely special, university town and pretty ok nightlife, very safe (as is all Finland). However, you can enter the archipelago from there and it's unique in all of europe or even the world. Some love it to bits, some are not that particular. There are cabins for rent and probably saunas in nearly all habitable islands.

Least recommended - tier (don't actually hate these but wouldnt go again unless necessary):

>Tunis
Well, went there before the Arab Spring and I'm fairly certain it's even shittier now.

>Essen, Germany
You can go there and see a mine. Concrete, not much to do. It's surrounded by nicer places to live probably, but its not for just visiting as a tourist.

>Oulu, Finland
Not much to see, despite being so far upnorth. It's a staging area for trips further north or the islands, but never clicked with the place.

>Reykjavik
The town itself is pretty small and not much to do unless you love whale watching, bathing and seeing the penis museum (OP?). However, Iceland itself is cool in many of the word's meanings.

>San Diego, california
Didn't love the place ,spent a few days, the city itself needs someone to guide you if you want to find anything worthy of seeing.
Still, liked the aircraft carrier - much freedoms for a small fee. Perhaps a nice place to live, however.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Best:

>Hong Kong:
Did my first solo trip here, was totally lost and confused the first day, but after that enjoyed it. Loved the views, amazing hikes, beaches, islands, hills, culture, shopping, amazing food, party scene, booming craft beer scene, chill atmospheres and all in such a close vicinity with amazing accessibility. The hike with the many waterfalls was a highlight, did it with just half a water bottle, a huge hangover and 3 hours of sleep, but loved it so much.

>Istanbul:
Huge city, so much variety in things to see and do. Cultural variety as well. Mosques just a few blocks away from the best Electronic music clubs you can imagine. One of my fav clubs worldwide was very close to Taksim. Turkish food is absolutely top tier, lots of culture and the friendliest people you can imagine. Extremely hectic traffic though, but I didnt mind it that much.

>Rome:
Really hard to choose between Rome and other Italian cities, but how can I choose against a full on open air museum? Great food, friendly people, so much to do and see. Only downside is vendors and a few homeless people, but they are really easy to avoid.

Honorable mentions:
>Florence, Bologna, Madrid, Plovdiv, Varna, Gdansk, Lisbon, Tokyo, Hiroshima, Taipei, Kuala Lumpur

Worst:

>Dubai
Easy pick. Fake and hot. Felt like a ghost town when I visited. Big buildings and huge malls with everything aimed at people who like burning money. Extremely ugly city.

>Paris
Its been a good time since I've been here, but if it wasn't the most chaotic day ever in my life. Many homeless people, druggies and retards just fighting, destroying stuff and creating hassles out of nothing.

>Hoi An
Definitely not as bad as Paris and Dubai. I usually don't really dislike stuff, but I was disappointed when I got here. The bridge is beautiful at night, I had some great craft beer here andgood food, but everything else is just a tourist trap. The bars are shit, the vendors are annoying and the city is ugly, outside of the bridge

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2392773
Bath is not just the Roman baths. The entire city is covered in Georgian architecture and elaborate parks. There's a very specific stone they only quarry there and it's probably one of the best stones for buildings in terms of aesthetics. It's a very, very rich town and it shows the very best of Britain. You can forget you live in England when you are in Bath. Just a stunning place. I worked there for a hostel for a year, the place is pure soul, also I met so many cool people there. BTW - you can get a resident card and enter the bath's for free. They're not too picky about proof of residence, you could literally book a hostel weeks before, have a letter mailed there and use that as a reference. It also works for other attractions and lasts 3 years. If you can be bothered with getting a bicycle, go down the canals to Dundas Aqueduct or cycle thru the mountain in what used to be the railway cutting thru Bath Hills - in fact I recommend hiking around the town on the same hills as you get great views. I detest most things about Britain, the weather, most of the people, ugly architecture, but Bath is an absolute pearl, it's undeniably one of the most beautiful places I have ever been.Somerset is the best place in England. Compared to other big cities Bristol isn't half bad, although I could never live there.

You have some immigration, but it's mostly Eastern Europeans and well educated people. So not really. It's mostly white British who live there. >>2396389
There's a regional ticket that covers a huge area. When I still used to use it, I always brought the one with the student discount - driver's never check anything if you're using the app. I made trips to Wells, Weston-Super-Mare, Cheddar, etc. with it. Bath alone can be done in probably a day or two, but I recommend a few days to explore the country side and smaller towns, also Bristol. It's probably one of the nicest corners of England.

Here's a trip I recommend.

Take a bike (or walk, but it will take longer).

Go to Come Down Tunnel, the northern end. Basically it's an old railway tunnel that is now a walking/cycling path. It quite long and it's always pretty cold inside, even during the summer. I've gone through it several times and I always get a slightly eerie feeling.

When you emerge, follow the green road towards Monkton Combe. It's a very, very classical English village. There's a pretty church and a cemetery. Then continue along towards Dundas Aqueduct. There the Bath canal crossed river Avon. There's also a railroad underneath and it's a good spot if you're into trainspotting. You can't miss it, it looks bigger than any of the photos in person. There you have the option to go to either Bradford on Avon as signed off with teal for a daytrip. There's another aqueduct on the way there, albeit it is less impressive. It gets more wooded after Dundas going towards Bradford, so if that is your jam you'll like it. Otherwise follow the blue line, along the canal, to go back to Bath. It's a very, very nice cycling trip all around. You're mostly following level ground too as you go directly under the hills in the first stage and then circumvent them going back.

Best done on a sunny day for full kino. May/June is probably the best time, everything is green, days are sunny and it doesn't rain that much.

>>2378143
You're wrong. You can get a room in Seville for like $400 a month, I know someone who is doing this. It's a nice college town, young sluts come from all over Europe on Erasmus.

If a Latino immigrant making 10€/hr picking strawberries can make it in Spain, you can too, ffs. You could get a room in a tier-one city like Madrid for like 700 bucks.

You just have to know where to look for an apartment. Don't use AirBnb for anything other than the short term. Go on local Facebook groups and ask where to get started looking.

If people find out you have a remote American income they'll be lining up to rent to you. I met a Brazilian guy willing to rent to me for $40 a night at the height of the tourist season in Barcelona. If you looked online you'd hardly be able to find anything for less than $200, if you were able to find anything at all. Wasn't a bad part of town either, even though in Spain "the bad part of town" is an absolute joke in terms of danger compared to the US, Latin America, France, etc.

You do have to be aware of scams. If a nigger starts video calling you asking for a deposit on a place you haven't been to, don't give him anything.

I've found that Spain is a nice middle ground for someone looking to live large on a remote income. It's a safe, clean white country that is full of attractive women, very cosmopolitan with a vast cultural wealth at the same time. The nightlife is out of this world. I was able to eat out twice a day and get drunk every night when I went, and I make less than $100k. Yes, it's difficult if you depend on the local economy to make a living, but if you make your money abroad it's an option that is definitely worth considering.

>>2390283
>I assume this relates to taxes as Montreal's COL on Numbeo looked manageable
For an American, it seems reasonable since living in a tier-one city like Montreal on our side of the border would be even more expensive than it is for them. But for them, the COL is absolute dogshit, you need to keep in mind that they don't make as much as we do. Their salaries aren't as high as ours in THEIR MONEY, and keep in mind that their dollar is weaker than ours. No wonder all you hear them do is bitch and complain.

Montreal is better than Anglo-Canada, but I still think you should rule it out. This is because you can get a city that's much more livable for the money you'll be spending in Canada elsewhere. I've enjoyed my time there very much, but that's because I have a (very sociable) friend there from college, and I'm fluent in French.

Obviously, it's Canada, so even the French-speaking young people will (generally) speak good English. But as my friend told me, it's something that you have to go out of your way to learn in school. He's a lawyer, it wasn't some lazy stoner who told me this. He was more dedicated to his English studies than most, and even he speaks it with a very heavy accent.

It's an acquired language for them, so when they're among themselves they'll be speaking French, and this will make it harder to break into social circles. I get compliments on my French all the time, from people on both sides of the Atlantic, and when I hear Québecois speak it among themselves even I find it hard to follow along. Their local dialect is heavy in their own slang that literally nobody else uses. You won't learn it in school and your semester abroad in France won't help at all.

It goes without saying that social circles will be the key to having a good life there like anywhere else. The Tinder scene is just as brutal as in America. If you're looking for a place that isn't as expensive as the US you're better off going to Spain.

>>2376981
I work for a major, international corporate entity.

I work from home, however, I use extremely specific software and rely on a data interface which is tightly relegated to my work laptop which they have provided me with.

To log on to my work laptop, I have to log in through a company VPN, which of course exposes my location.

My company is extremely anal about security. I have a cunt of a line manager, which makes it near impossible for me to raise the question of working abroad with her. I know she’ll get uppity and cause problems; the main reason being that if I have technical issues with my laptop, which happens often due to the precarious nature of our software, I’m required to go to my place of work and get the IT team to take a look.

My question is this. If I use 5g on my mobile, using my home SIM on international roaming, and use that to hotspot my laptop, would they be able to tell my true location?

The reason I ask is that whenever I use my sim abroad, I find that I’m still using my home countries internet services. Google is in English, my advertisements are all in England and the same that I get at home. It’s not until I connect to local WiFi that I get foreign ads etc.

Anyone got any advice?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390824
>My question is this. If I use 5g on my mobile, using my home SIM on international roaming, and use that to hotspot my laptop, would they be able to tell my true location?
I'd say 98% yes - the remote IP address they'll see you connecting from will be an IP address belonging to the foreign telco provider. It won't be one of the IP addresses of your home telco provider.
The 2% chance I'm holding back is because I'm aware some telcos do have the options of SIMs with fixed IP addresses tied to them. Without knowing where you are from and what telco you use, I've gotta put that chance as low.
>The reason I ask is that whenever I use my sim abroad, I find that I’m still using my home countries internet services. Google is in English, my advertisements are all in England and the same that I get at home. It’s not until I connect to local WiFi that I get foreign ads etc.
I wouldn't put too much weight on this, but you could tell pretty easily by visiting whatsmyip.com while using your SIM abroad and seeing what it says.

There are ways you can get around having a foreign IP address. Others have probably talked about them already, but they come down to using a router or gateway device that can use a VPN. On that device you'd use a VPN (preferably to a friend's home network in your home country, but maybe ExpressVPN will work for you since many of their exit nodes are partnered with local ISPs). Then you connect your work laptop to that router/gateway device. Your work laptop connects to the company VPN and your company VPN sees it coming from the personal/ExpressVPN address your router/gateway is using. If you do this route, you need a router/gateway that with a killswitch that will completely drop your internet interface if the VPN drops.
I think your big problem is having flaky work software that require you to bring the laptop to the office to fix. Maybe get a second work laptop for your "month at the cottage"?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390824
>If I use 5g on my mobile, using my home SIM on international roaming, and use that to hotspot my laptop, would they be able to tell my true location?
Yeah, they would. International roaming depends on your carrier's agreement with some local carrier to provide you service in order to work. So when you try to log in, it'll show that country's location.

And it's not a guarantee you'll be able to get 5G wherever you go. Even in Europe. I paid my American carrier for unlimited roaming internet while abroad (again, it was a French carrier providing me the actual service, you can only do this a few months before they cut you off anyway), and I bought a French SIM card, and even then, the best I could get was 4G.

Besides that, if your company really is anal about security then there's no way in hell you'll be able to hide the fact that you're abroad from them. The fact that you would even ask this means you aren't technically sophisticated enough to outwit your IT department. You'd only end up getting yourself in trouble.

My advice would be that, if working abroad means that much to you (and I can understand that, because it's a life-changing perk) then I would suggest you look for a job with a company that's willing to look the other way. This means banks and security work are probably a no-go for you (though there are surely exceptions). You should be looking for a new job constantly anyway, so that your compensation is as high as it can be.

Many companies won't allow you to work from abroad, if only to save themselves the tax and legal troubles they would have to figure out in another country. But if you use an American mailing address (say, your parents') and give them plausible deniability, many companies are willing to look the other way to keep valuable employees, including mine.

I've been to the Maldives a few times and I wouldn't suggest doing what you're doing.

Also, although Beautiful Maldives is a honeymoon destination so you will get very little to no chat to anyone while you're away. If you want the chilled out beach life id suggest heading to Thailand, Bali or or even somewhere like Mauritius. Your money will go further, you'll have more fun and you will get accommodation that's twice as good as what you're looking at in the Maldives for about 1/4 of the price. Diving is cheap, lots more tourists and all in all a better experience for a solo traveller.
If you want to do Maldives then I'd suggest one of the cheaper all inclusive islands as it'll cost you a fortune if you don't have that, you can't just go to a shop on any of these islands unless you stay on male which is a dump and looks nothing like your pic.

I used to do a lot of road trips in the US. I found that if I used highways and mostly followed the speed limit, I could count on averaging between 55 and 65 miles per hour with stops to eat, fuel up, smoke, use the toilet, etc. The 55 mph pace is taking it easy, doing sit down meals, etc. The 65 mph pace is making short stops. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The five ex-Soviet "Stans" aren't as much talked about as other destinations despite offering a lot to visitors.
I have lived and travelled through them, so let me give you an overview in case you're interested.

posts.name: Kazakhstan
posts.com:
The biggest of five countries and also the country with subjectively the least number of obvious tourist attractions.
What makes up for it is the sheer size of the country, you can spend days going across by train and experience the diversity of landscapes from snow-capped mountains, empty steppe to plain old desert.

The big split is between North and South, with the less-visited North featuring the Dubai-esque capital Astana (formerly Nur-Sultan, formerly Astana) and the "Russian" provinces and the Karaganda desert, the South having multiple historical cities dotted along the border.

Most people will visit Almaty, the most successful example of a modernised Soviet city and also the only place where you can eat at western fast-food chains that aren't KFC for a change.
Near Almaty you can find a lot of mountainous nature such as the Big Almaty Lake (pic related), valleys and nature parks towards China but also a glimpse into China at the Khorgos Special Economic Zone where duty is charged by the kilo.
Almaty and Bishkek in Kyrgyzstan are 4 hours and about 10 dollars apart by car, you can easily fly into either city and reach the other on the same day.

A underrated place is the South-West: On the way from or to Uzbekistan you can make a detour for a day trip to newly-renovated Turkestan and Taraz is also worth stopping over for a couple hours.
The highway between Almaty and Shymkent is a racetrack, especially at night, so if you want to keep your nerves just use one of the frequent trains.

Western Kazakhstan is partially located in Europe and can be used as a starting point towards the Caucasus and Russia by low-cost carrier and frequent overnight trains.
On the way you will pass Baikonur, sadly only legally accessible through overpriced tours, launches can be seen from outside, sneaking in can be risky, especially in the current political climate.

posts.name: Kyrgyzstan
posts.com:
The "Switzerland of Central Asia" has the most liberal visa regime, most Westerners will be able to stay for 60 days without any visa or other bureaucratic hurdles.

Everybody will pass through Bishkek, the poorer, more "Soviet" cousin of Almaty, especially if you need a visa for any neighbouring country.
The city itself can be visited in a day, two if you're interested in bazars, Alamedin, Dordoi and Osh bazar being the ones recommended for a comprehensive experience.
The city may be boring to visit but is very comfortable to live due to low price levels and everything a second world dweller being in walking distance.

The main draw of Kyrgyzstan is the nature, be it the surprisingly good ski resort near Karakol, the never-freezing Issyk-Kul, the countless valleys featuring yurts and hot springs, the mountain passes towards the South and the changed Kyrgyz part of the Fergana valley.
If you are fine with not being spoken to in English you can get nature excursions for low, be it guided hikes, ski transfers to yurt stays with optional horse riding.
Try to get excursions with meals prepared by locals, during summer you will usually get loads of fresh vegetables and fruits to complement the meat-laden main dishes.

posts.name: Tajikistan
posts.com:
The non-Turk outlier of the region that is heavily influenced by Persian culture has become more open recently, with most westerners being able to enter visa-free for 30 days.
You still need to get a separate permit to visit the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonmous Oblast, but you should be able to get it on the way in Dushanbe.

Despite being the poorest country (salary-wise), as a tourist you end up spending more money than in neighbouring Kyrgyzstan, be it on transport, accommodation or imported goods.

Tajikistan has some dishes that you cannot find in the surrounding countries, a blessing if you have been in rural areas for a while and are getting tired of plov, samsas and noodles.
Many expats say that Dushanbe feels a bit like Pyongyang, with police checking beards and headwear to prevent extremism from taking root and the limited number of places to go after work where you will end up meeting the same people anyway.

If you're in Tashkent for more than two days and getting bored you can do an overnight trip to Khujand across the border to see what the city would have looked like before the reconstructions.

Because of the border conflict and other border closures you will not be able to enter Kyrgyzstan without taking a detour via Uzbekistan, easy to do from Khujand or Dushanbe, more annoying when you're deep in the GBAO.

posts.name: Turkmenistan
posts.com:
There are two way to see Turkmenistan, the expensive and comprehensive way using a North Korea style tour with a guide and driver or by rushing through the country on a transit visa between Iran and Uzbekistan.
If on a tour everything will be taken care of, just pay the amount requested and enjoy the ride.
If you successfully managed to get a transit visa then you will spend your time and cash moving between towns in trains and shared taxis with locals, haggling with hotels for low rates, bribing officials with dollars and cigarettes (which seem to have become more and more valuable in the last year, an open pack can save you queues and inspections without much suspicion.

The most popular transit visa route is between Urgench/Khiva and Mashad, within three days you can see unique nature (pic related), a historical city and the shiny marble capital.

posts.name: Uzbekistan
posts.com:
In the "Big Three" cities of Samarkand/Bukhara/Khiva you will find the closes to mass tourism, with European boomers spending their retirement money on souvenirs to bring back to their boomer friends.
Still, it's nowhere near the levels of any European tourist city, even at the most popular sites you can just wait five minutes and you'll be only be sharing it with domestic tourists and local touts.

While the Big Three are what draw the most people, on a longer visit you may want to check out more nature-based destinations such as Karakalpakstan, site of what used to be the Aral Sea or the Fergana Valley where the above-mentiond souvenirs are actually made.

Moving between regions can be done by train or by domestic flight via Tashkent.
While the flights are comfortable and not too expensive, you can save money and experience authentic Uzbekistan by taking an overnight train, especially if you book third class (platzkart). If you find out that the experience is too authentic for you, you can easily bribe the conductor to find you a private compartment for about 10 to 15 dollars.

While Tashkent might be your entry point, you will quickly find out that it's a fairly boring city, especially the nightlife when compared to Almaty and Bishkek.
Sadly for the inclined tourist there are less and less Soviet-era buildings left untouched in Tashkent, but a simple trip to any neighbouring country will satisfy your cravings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What you definitely need are some skills reading Cyrillic, even in countries that formally switched to Roman characters.
With only English you won't get as far somebody who speaks just even basic Russian, English services are generally available but come at a premium.
Just using some basic greetings in the respective local languages will usually be met with enthusiasm, even if you then continue in Russian or pidgin English-Russian.

Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan are the two countries where you won't stand out as a white Westerner due to the high number of ethnic Russians, even at bazars you will get the same treatment as locals, at least until you open your mouth. Usually, this will work to your advantage, but be prepared to be talked to in Rapid Russian.

The region has a reputation of being dangerous, mostly due to the proximity to Afghanistan, but as a tourist the biggest risk you'll face is road traffic, some taxi rides will make even the most euphoric atheist pray for a safe journey.

In most cities you can save yourself a lot of trouble by installing the Yandex Taxi app, the local equivalent to Uber. Even just showing the app prices will give you stronger hand while haggling, never use a metered taxi without fixating a price first, it's an invitation to get ripped off.

Tourist SIM cards are available in every country, the easiest being in Kyrgyzstan where they'll just hand them out for free at busy border crossings, the most expensive being in Turkmenistan (and you may not be able to use shitpost on /int/), see the ever-useful Prepaid SIM Card Wiki for more details.

The best English internet site for this region is Caravanistan, some of the articles may become outdated but the forum will usually have the relevant updates.
I'll check this thread for questions and try to answer until this thread dies, so ask away!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>That being said, what’s the best time of the year to visit them?
You can visit all year around, but each region has its "best" season.
The desert parts of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and the whole of Turkmenistan are best visited in spring and autumn because it can get hot in summer, easily more than 40°C for days, although dry heat, so more bearable than similar humid destinations.
The mountain parts of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan have their main season in summer when you can hike everywhere and all the summer facilities are open. In winter there are fewer places where you can go skiing and winter hiking, but in early spring and late autumn you'll find many places closed.
TL;DR: summer/winter for mountains, spring/autumn for the rest

>My russian is very very basic, will I survive?
Little Russian is already better than no Russian.
Learn some useful common phrases (e.g. Pimsleur Russian) and download an offline translator. Make sure that you have a Russian keyboard enabled in case somebody wants to translate to English.
I personally make sure to write down any amounts negotiated (especially taxi fares) on paper or on my phone and show them to prevent and misunderstandings or "misunderstandings" (i.e. scams).

>Lastly, what’s that flag chart?
It's the flags of the five countries crossed with each other!
You can see the original flags on the diagonal from top left to bottom right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>What would be the best order or “loop” to visit the stans?
If you have visa-free access to Uzbekistan I'd pass through there multiple times because you can get to all the other countries from there.
The KG-TJ border is closed and will likely remain closed for the time being, so Tajikistan is pretty much only accessible from Uzbekistan.
Having said that it's all a matter of preference and (time) budget.
If Turkmenistan opens (to how it used to be in 2019) I would enter from Iran on a transit visa via the Mashad-Ashgabat-Khiva route because that way you won't have to worry about carrying large amounts of cash afterwards.
From there I'd do the "Big Three" Khiva->Bukhara->Samarkand before crossing the border to Panjakent (TJ), going down to Dushanbe, the base for planning any activities in the GBAO.
The return from Dushanbe would be via Khujand to Tashkent, if you don't want to do the Anzob twice, you can also go via Termez, possible even by train.
From Tashkent you can either go North to see more desert/steppe in Kazakhstan or East to the Fergana valley, ending up in Osh (KG).
From there you can do the 10-hour ride to Bishkek, stopping over in Toktogul for a night if you want.
In Northern Kyrgyzstan, you will very likely spend some time in Issyk-Kul, both on the lake and the surrounding mountains, stopping over in Karakol before heading towards Almaty, easily reached via Bishkek, the more adventurous and scenic path via the Karakara valley.
From Almaty you can go West to Taraz/Shymkent/Turkestan for the Silk Road sights or North to Karaganda and Astana (not much to see but surprisingly cool during summer due it being very windy).

Obviously this is a very packed itinerary for a two-months, so you want to drop destinations and flesh out your stay at others.
You can do 4 out of 5 countries in less than 24 hours (by bus and taxi between Khujand TJ and Bishkek KG), but that's neither relaxing nor recommended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>Where would you spend most of your time?
It really depends on what you like:
Like mountains? Then you'll have the best time in Kyrgyzstan where you can spend months in the mountains if you desire.
Like history that isn't just rock carvings and shards? You'll be best served with Uzbekistan, both the "Big Three" and smaller destinations like the countless fortresses in the desert.

All countries but Turkmenistan give you ample time to visit and visa runs can be had for cheap.

It is really easy to go country collecting (my passport has pages and pages filled with entry and exit stamps due to extended weekend trips), but in the end you do not want to rush from one place to the next because of a tight itinerary.
Yes, you can visit Khiva/Bukhara in one day, but strolling through town in the late evening or early morning with nobody else in sight is something you can only do if you spend a night or two there.
The same can be said about chilling on the shores of Issyk-Kul or spending a lazy day in a yurt camp reading a book while listening to nature.

Anyway, let me know if you want to know more about a place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Food wise, how’s the food?
There's a reason why the region isn't a gourmet travel destination: The local dishes aren't much to write home about.
You'll have a lot of meat and grease and many dishes will start to feel similar after being here for some time.
The good thing is that the Soviet time brought foreign dishes that are now a staples of the local diet everywhere.
One of them are salads influenced by ethnic Koreans, available in all bazaars, most restaurants, delicatessen and supermarkets.
On a regular day, at least one of my meals contains whatever kind of salad I feel like that day. On bazaars they're usually home-made, sold by middle-aged women, most of them will let you try before buying, use that opportunity to sample, same applies for confectionery sold there.
I personally avoid "Pizza&Sushi" places, most of them don't do either right. Bigger cities have both proper pizzerias and sushi bars if you want to mix things up a little.

People are very proud of their bread (pic related), try to spot the differences between regions.
Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan have surprisingly good dairy products, just be aware that they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West.
Try whatever produce is in season, local fruits and vegetables are usually very tasty and fresh due to short supply chains. Again, they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West, probably because the local agriculture is less developed and therefore uses fewer modern preservatives.

If you're taking the train, take some vegetables, fruits and bread to share because the locals love to feed foreigners and see their reactions to local food and it's nice to be able to share as well.
Trains always have hot water, so instant noodles and mashed potatoes will be a safe backup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>What I can’t absolutely miss?
Try the "signature dishes" of the region like plov, lagman, beshparmak, manty, samsa.
Eat the ones you like again, preferably at small places, the shorter the menu, the better the dishes.

In Kyrgyzstan, especially in Issyk-Kul you have to try Ashlan-Fu (pic related), a Chinese-style cold noodle soup with vinegar (works very well for hangovers).
In Tajikistan you have to try Kurutob, a salad made from bread that for some reason you can't find in the neighbouring countries.
Don't forget about local minorities: Uyghurs and Dungans have some nice dishes, as have the ethnic Koreans that operate the Korean restaurants found in every bigger city.

If it's your first trip to the former USSR then you should definitely try what the other republics have to offer, be it Moldovan/Georgian/Azeri wine, Russian and Georgian cuisine or just plain old Ukrainian sweets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Also, is there a sim card that works in all of them?
It's cheaper and less hassle to buy a SIM card in each country than to see what roaming offers are available.
Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan can be annoying by requiring a hardware registration if you want to use a local SIM card for more than a month.
You can avoid that by roaming using a Kyrgyz SIM card, but that's too much of a hassle unless you're living in Kyrgyzstan, especially since you'll need to figure out the offers and how to top up from abroad if needed.
Roaming from abroad is usually expensive, the least expensive place for Europeans being Kazakhstan, in the rest of the region a local SIM card reigns supreme.
If you're just passing through Turkmenistan then you shouldn't waste your time hunting for a SIM card, if you're on a tour then your guide will be able to help you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370901
You're going to be spending some money - a budget tour of 4 days and 3 nights from a Western agency runs about 1000 dollars, for an additional 400 dollars you'll get 8 nights and 9 days in the country.
Obviously some local tour operator might be able to shave off some dollars from the quoted prices above, but most of the costs are set by the Turkmen government, so no getting around that.
This is the major reason why transit visa runs through the country are popular, you save money and have more (limited) freedom to choose your way through the country.

Any well-stocked tour agency can book you a tour to Turkmenistan, they all need to cooperate with some companies within the country that can issue the relevant invitation letters.
Have a look on the internet what interests you and get quotes from different companies, no need to pay more for the same service.
Caravanistan might start up their middleman services once the country opens and they get confirmations of things running again.

Yes, the road between Dushanbe and Khujand is the major road of Tajikistan, so they go through great pains to keep it open the whole year.
On the way you'll pass through the infamous Anzob tunnel, nicknamed "the tunnel of death" because it was operating for ten year while unfinished, but since about 2016 this is not the case any more, now it's just another long tunnel with the usual traffic dangers present in the region.

If you want to be absolutely sure to keep to your schedule you can plan to go via Termez/Samarkand/Oybek in Uzbekistan, their roads and rails are open all year round without major problems.

The people in the region are conservative and there's a big gap between rural and city people.
In the countryside, "dating" will consist of convincing the village elders that you're a suitable groom, a very difficult task unless you have spent significant time there and have immersed in the local language and culture.
In cities you'll face the typical dating pattern found in more conservative countries: The man leads the date and pays for everything and the woman tries to look her best.
Many young locals do know some English but are hesitant to speak, with many of them becoming quite fluent speakers once they're drunk.
Even women with a liberal worldview are sexually conservative and like to show off their housewife skills by wanting to feed you with food they cook, showing off their bargaining skills or even offering to fix the shirt you tore during your date.
You will also quickly get to know her brothers/cousins/friends who will invite you to their activities consisting of drinking, smoking and all kinds of sports and physical activities to judge you for themselves.
Speaking Russian and/or the local language will definitely help your chances in all stages of the process.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2392578
Your best bet would be to spend your two months studying in Bishkek.
There are a couple reasons why:
- welcoming visa-free regime, 60 days for citizens of many countries, easy visa runs if you want to stay longer
- Russian is the lingua franca, the locals speak it well and without hesitation
- there are multiple language schools catering to foreign students like you, both short-term and long-term, offering group and private lessons
- there are many teachers and tutors available to hire

As for costs, you can easily keep your expenses at 1000 dollars or less if you compromise a bit by either staying a bit outside the city centre, not eating out every meal or pregaming before going out in the evening.
Even if you don't compromise at all, you will not spend much more in Bishkek.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

>Also, suppose I stay 2 months learning Russian, which of the five stans should I choose to live that long?
I would base myself in Bishkek in a small apartment and take private lessons at one of the schools so that you can easily take extended weekend trips in the region, both in Kyrgyzstan and nearby Southern Kazakhstan.
Almaty is only about 4 hours away (door-to-door) and both FRU and ALA have flights to nearby cities if you are not keen on riding taxis, buses or trains for long.

posts.com: Will be in Astana in 2 weeks. Any advice? What should I see outside of the obvious?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393052
Since you'll be there in the middle of winter prepare to spend most of your time indoors, as Astana weather can be unforgiving with double-digit negative temperatures and strong gusts of wind.
Definitely plan some time for museums, the National museum can take you half a day, the Military museum is interesting & free and who knows how long the Nazarbayev museum will stay open.
Definitely take a look at all the weird buildings that were placed in the city within the last 5 years, in summer you can walk around all day, in winter you will want to do that by taxi as the bus system is not very suitable for tourists and distances are surprisingly large.
As for hanging out, pick any of the malls for people watching, the Khan Shatyr has an indoor amusement park and paid beach.
The "old part of town" North of the river feels more like a Kazakh city, the Artem bazar is where you can get most of your shopping done, including the tasty salads traditionally sold at bazars all over Central Asia.

As for food, the various food courts can be surprisingly good, if you're tired of Kazakh food try Daredzahni for Georgian food, there's a Ukrainian restaurant nearby as well.

That Pegasus overnight flight arriving at 05:00 in the morning isn't bad, just try to get sleepy before boarding and the 5 hours will just fly by.
The plane is fairly new and any delay will only make you arrive closer to daytime.

Remember to not pay more than 700~800 som for the taxi ride to the city, always negotiate before getting into the taxi, if you can get Yandex Taxi installed on your phone before arriving you'll have an even easier time.
Worst case you can take the shuttle bus into town, costs around 200 som and runs every 20 minutes, just take a left after customs.

You can get both SIM cards and cash in the airport, there are SIM card vendors accepting KGS/USD/EUR between passport control and baggage claim as well as outside, plus a load of ATMs without ripoff rates just to the right after customs.

Have fun and try not to get too smoked by the winter air!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393984
I'd definitely try to check in early, with or without paying for an additional night.
Pretty much all places have a night guard, so you will not stand in front of locked doors in the morning.

>How cash/cashless is Kyrgystan?
Very cash-based. There are more and more places where you can pay by card, but it's usually quicker to just pay cash, unlike Kazakhstan where QR payments are getting the norm.
I usually pay big expenses by card and anything else cash, carrying about KGS 5000 (about USD 60) with me in my wallet, another 5000 back at home.
There are two banks, Halyk and Optima that will allow you ATM withdrawals without additional commission.
>I guess I'll buy a SIM card at the airport.
Good idea, you can set up everything while waiting for your luggage to come out plus the airport vendors speak some English.
Currently O! has the best offers, but check the Prepaid SIM card wiki for details.
>In Turkey, it was a pain in the ass to get a SIM card anywhere else.
In Kyrgyzstan they literally give them away for free at border crossings and you can buy them anywhere in the city.
> Am I right to assume that Ala Too Square is the very heart of the city?
Yeah, but anywhere on Prospekt Chuy can be considered central.
Anything in the square between Zhibek Zholu in the North, Alamedin River in the East, the railroad in the South and Osh bazar to the West is easily reached on foot or by countless buses/marshrutkas.
There's a coal power plant to the East, keep that in mind in terms of air pollution, the South has cleaner air, but if you're sensitive you should avoid Bishkek in winter anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous

As usual, don't give pickpockets a chance and keep your valuables at home, but being from Brazil you should already know that, no offence.

I've heard good things from both the London School and LinguaYurt with their programmes for foreigners, both group classes and individual lessons.
There are some cheaper schools as well targeted at locals, usually offering Russian, Turkish and English, but from what I've heard you'll be in bigger classes studying together with rural Kyrgyz on how to speak enough Russian to be a migrant labourer in Russia.
