Argie here, I'm seeing a handful of misconceptions about this place and the surrounding countries, so I'll clarify a couple things. Feel free to ask about anything else you have doubts about.

For one, this is not a "globohomo-free" country. Quite the opposite, in fact. Save for Uruguay, this is the most pozzed country in latin america. The government is more preoccuppied with preventing "hateful discourse" and forcing a butchered "inclusive" version of the spanish language than taking care of the one half of our population who's living below the poverty line. Not to mention most sides of the political spectrum haven't necessarily adopted but have at least accepted and allowed this shit to happen.
A second thing to note, I have no idea why you'd want to live in a country that has been edging at the brink of economic collapse for decades. Unless you feel like Lord Miles wasn't enough of a retard, I see no reason to leave your home to come live in a place like this. Also, you better like taxes, because you're gonna see a lot of them.
As for the surrounding countries, Uruguay has a great quality of life and everything outside Montevideo is fucking empty. Paraguay and Bolivia are alright, they're somehow less corrupt and more stable than we are. Chile is good, they recently elected a leftie, so people are panicking about them going the way of Venezuela and yours truly, but if you ask me, he seems like a very down-to-earth guy when compared to the usual, blind, retarded ideologues every other country gets when they elect a left-wing politician.

Yup, government sponsored, too.

Back in the day when the country got its independence, our caudillos (pretty much spanish for "warlord") raided the south and genocided the shit out of every native tribes they could find. Somehow, this one survived and ended up becoming a what's essentially a cold war-style left-wing guerrilla terrorist group.

Once every few weeks, you'll hear of them terrorizing the people living in and around Neuquén, Río Negro, Chubut, and rarely Santa Cruz and southern Mendoza. They're always fighting with locals and "reclaiming" land belonging to the mapuche nation (look up "wallmapu" to see the extent of their larp).
The government, being your typical, run-of-the-mill leftie activist group, loves turning a blind eye to it. The last bit of news I remember hearing about is them intervening to take land away from the army to give it to one of these groups and the ensuing shitstorm that followed. Last year they spent like a whole month raiding the town of El Bolsón, to the point the locals got tired of nobody doing shit and took it in their own hands to literally ride on horses and hunt them down cowboy style. It was pretty surreal.

That said, it's not unlivable. Many popular tourist destinations are smack-dab in the middle of mapuche territory. Their numbers are far smaller here than in Chile, so the real problem lies on the other side of the Andes, it's just that here they have free reign to fuck with people.
If you see pic related, stay wary.

>>2332641
>how's the crime in the smaller cities and towns?
There used to be places here where there wasn't much to fear years ago, but the country is going downhill hard, so those places are starting to feel it.
That said, it will be less common than in the big cities. I won't say anywhere near zero, but it's harder to get away with shit when the place is small and everybody knows each other, lel. Town life is mostly chill, but far poorer depending on where you go (the north especially).
>Let's say a town of about 10k -- is there cartel bullshit going on there, or in any of the countryside?
Doubt it, most of the drug trafficking happens around/in the outskirts of the bigger cities (the exception being Rosario, where the WHOLE city is the argentinian equivalent of a mexican narco state, stay the fuck away).
>Do you feel safer in general in the smaller towns than you do in the cities?
Crime can always happen. You will be more "exposed" in small towns and you might be in trouble if you're hurt badly or feel unsafe at a particular moment in time, because small town hospitals have few resources and not as many policemen, while you'll be more prone to it in the cities but at least there are more resources/people to help you. "Safety" kinda depends on how much you can fend for yourself.
>How are the real estate prices there compared to La Tierra de las Hamburguesas?
Don't know much about that, actually, but I can tell you two things:
-Buenos Aires has been having problems reminiscent to that of London this year. Shit is too expensive and too small, so nobody wants it.
-As for the whole country in general, prices are just going up like everything else, so if you're planning to buy something, make sure you bring in as much foreign currency as you can so you don't have to start collecting Monopoly money that will have both lost its value and fallen short of the new price by the time you have it.

Tons of options, red meat in general is awesome but there's also exceptionally good pizzas and ice cream. You can eat a 4-star meal for less than 10 usd.
As for more traditional foods, you can try locro, empanadas, guiso, and if you like sweet stuff, anything with dulce de leche. Like alfajores or facturas that you can buy in panaderias. Croissants with dulce de leche are a must.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2327930
And about the drinking there's pretty good regional beer, and the last decade breweries have opened everywhere in most cities. IPA, APA, scottish, pale, etc.
I don't personally drink wine, but Argentinian wine is highly regarded as one of the best in the world. I've seen tourists praise even the cheap ones.
Decent whisky, outside of your typical brands
Not much vodka, tequila or rum, even though there is enough variety
And then there is Fernet. Mixed with Coke. Oh boy, it has a strong taste so it's a hit or miss, but if it hits, it's heaven.

If you're wondering about non-añcoholic drinks, meh. I guess we have mate, which is an infusion, sorta like herb tea, served on a wooden bowl (also called mate). It's more of a social thing, people sit together and pass the mate around, while chilling, or eating some snacks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2385358
Obviously you will not be fluent in 3 months (that is a task for a lifetime) but with 3 months of serious, consistent effort, you can learn the 2000 or so words you need to express basically any non-abstract thought or request.

It won't feel like much beforehand, but I did this exact thing (learn the 2000 most common words and practice listening/speaking every day for an hour for 3 months) before going to Russia, and the way people treat you with even that level of the language is remarkably different than if you are totally helpless. Most importantly, it turns basic things like ordering food or asking directions into an opportunity for an interesting interaction, rather than a tooth-pulling simulation.

And I know this sort of advice does not actually work on a person who becomes anxious:, but regardless: do remember that most tourists have no knowledge of the country's language whatsoever, so literally anything you can say or do in the language puts you far ahead of the average. From your perspective it might seem embarrassing to struggle with the language, but whatever monolingual person you're talking to is probably quite happy you're attempting to accommodate them, and feels no "vicarious embarrassment" for you.

Also, with that base, you can just barely start to have full conversations with people if you have a knack for languages and, believe me, the same country is two entirely different places when you can speak the language (even a little) vs. when you cant.

For Castles you have Cardiff Castle and Caerphilly. You can go to the Roman museum in Caerleon (it's a good day trip from Cardiff and accessible with public transport) and see the remains of a Roman amphitheater there and Roman museum.
For Arthur/Merlin stuff you can visit Craig-y-Dinas in the vale of Neath where according to legend Arthur is inside asleep. Some other legends say it was the last place in Britain that faeries were seen.
Also in the area you have some pretty cool waterfalls which are an easy to walk to and the Dan Yr Ogof caves which are open to tourists aren't so far away.

Dropping some links if you want to take a look:

http://britishfolklore.com/craig-y-dinas
https://snowdonia.gov.wales/walk/craig-y-ddinas/
https://www.cardiffcastle.com/
https://museum.wales/roman/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waterfall_Country_(Wales)
https://waterfallcountry.wales/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_yr_Ogof
https://www.showcaves.co.uk/

It's not too bad at places with a high elevation unless there's a heat wave. Joshua Tree will be too hot but Arches or even the top of GC will be fine. Anything in the pnw will be very comfy.

You're really not getting out of crowded national parks if you insist on going during the busiest time of the year.

Yellowstone is great, favorite national park I've been to, it's just unique and diverse. I also prefer to avoid crowds but it can't be helped at Yellowstone at the main attractions. The crowds at Yellowstone don't really bother me like the crowds on popular trails somewhere like Glacier or Grand Teton. I guess because if I'm hiking a trail I expect that sense of being out in the wilderness, leaving the developed world behind and going out into the mountains. But the popular trails in those parks are basically a conga line of people, it's very off putting and also annoying having to or being unable to pass people. Meanwhile in Yellowstone the main attractions are never far from the road, usually on a boardwalk or paved path so it doesn't really feel like I'm going out into the wild and other people being around doesn't bother me. Of course there are also great backcountry areas in Yellowstone with barely a soul around.

>>2396588

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Ok so about 2 or so weeks ago I posted a rough idea of a trip schedule and took in some advice and feedback from people who live in or have been to the UK. This is the current revision of the trip. Just keep in mind I am planning for 6 people and I had to go out of my way to hit a bunch of the iconic landmarks to please everyone so it's not the most optimized but I tried my best. I also would have planned for a trip longer than 14 days but it was hard to get all the schedules lined up in the first place.

Days 1-3: London
Day 4: Dover
Day 5: Peak District National Park
Day 6: York
Day 7: Northumberland
Days 8-9: Edinburgh
Day 10: Cairngorms National Park
Day 11: Loch Ness
Day 12: Lake District National Park
Day 13 Snowdonia
Day 14: Bath and Stonehenge

Now it might seem like a lot but I already cut out a ton of stuff. We are used to driving a lot on trips so this shouldn't be too bad. We did Italy in a similar manner and were able to see a lot of it except Venice. At least on Google maps the travel time looked to be reasonable. We already have a large rental van, but will be using the tube in London.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
there is a wales thread currently that has mentioned places near snowdonia.
snowdonia itself - at llanberis i think is the access point for the railway up the mountain. there is also a ruined castle across the street.
In the region around snowdonia there are many castles not far away.
Conwy (i think on your route), Caenarfon are the more famous, also a bit out of your way are Beaumaris and Harlech - maybe you will be castle'd out and just want the mountains and valleys this time if its not readily accessible.
the north coast of wales like around colwyn bay is an oldschool beach holiday back when travel wasn't as easy, so there are lots of old fashioned piers in many of these towns - its not a draw in itself but its a thing that exists.

do you care about bridges? the Flintshire bridge seams pretty neat, its only slightly diversion off the main motorway to snowdonia

the Menai Bridge is an old suspension bridge, nice area to walk around that but again, neat if in the area, not more interesting than snowdonia.

speaking of bridges - depending how you leave wales if you went towards shrewsbury and birmingham before going to bath/stonehenge, you might pass the town of ironbridge, home to the oldest ironbridge. you might also pass naer pontcysyllte aqueduct and Chirk Aqueduct which i always thought it was neat that they are for boats, but maybe thats not so unique

Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch is in this region, the supposed longest train station name. not too much draw apart from the name. its on island of Anglesey rural island with nice coastal walks

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dover to the Peak District is a long fucking drive, as you’ll have to deal with the M25 which is where aids came from

Why are you going to dover anyway? Dover castle is pretty good with some structures from the Romans if you like that kind of thing. But the rest of it sucks. I’d just go to the peaks direct from London. Go up Mam Tor and that pass just after Castleton. I had the nicest fried breakfast in a biker cafe in monyash.

Stonehenge is crap, they don’t actually let you near it and you can see it from the A303 anyway. Avebury stone circle is better. If you want Neolithic stuff find a Brexit voter lel

That drive Loch Ness -> Cumbria goes through Glencoe and some other areas. If the weather’s nice then this is one of the planet’s most scenic roads. Have a look down Glen Etive when you’re there. Also get a haggis supper from a chip shop while you’re here.

Thing with roads in the U.K. especially the rural ones is they’re pretty narrow and windy. It’ll feel twice as many miles as it is if you’re coming from USA.

Seems a solid enough route for a beauty spot focused holiday. You're probably going to do this but get everyone together for "I want to do X when we're at Y" and also have alternate options if possible for sucky weather, being worn out, wanting to do something historical instead of something purely admiring countryside (or vice versa). Even in summer, allow for miserable weather.

You've got a couple of four hour drives that are going to be draining on the person driving (long drive along motorways with narrow country roads at the ends). You'll need to decide if you want hotels at that days location or if you want them placed to break up the driving. Most motorways have services every 20 minutes or so (you get warnings if you're approaching the last services on a motorway). don't think you really have them in the US but they're reasonably large food court style things that tend to have 3 or 4 fast food places and a Starbucks or Costa , break up the trip and stops the driver getting too tired. Do not get petrol from them, they're obscenely expensive (up to 30p a litre more than typical petrol prices), fill up at a petrol station before you get onto a motorway, supermarkets often have the cheapest fuel.

Don't eat at a Wetherspoons pub, do try an Indian restaurant, try a carvery (avoid Stonehouse ones, Crown or Toby's are fine, independent ones are variable but can be among the nicest, check reviews), Try an all English breakfast (available all over the place at varying quality, look for good reviews, Beefeaters do a nice quality "all you can order" buffet. Avoid tourist trap Fish & Chips (most places in London). You can try a cheeky Nandos if you've ever wondered about the meme (and be disappointed when they're not exactly bad but not worth the hype)

Temple Bar with friends is fun albeit expensive.

We also have a wax museum in dublin which is, again small but fun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
At the Cliffs of Moher, there is the main carpark where you have to pay €12 for admission but there's a smaller carpark nearby. If approaching from the south, it's a left turn before you reach the visitor centre and will be indicated by a sign that says "Guerin's Path to Cliff Walk". If approaching from the North for some reason, it will be on the right after you pass the visitor centre. I think they charge €3 to park there. You can then walk to the visitor centre along the cliff path. You're supposed to have a ticket to get into the centre but if there's no employee standing at the main entrance then you definitely won't be asked for a ticket and you can walk straight in. There's an exhibition with information about the cliffs inside, as well as a gift shop, café and restaurant. O'Brien's tower is the highest point on the cliffs so I would recommend going there for sure to get cool views.
>t. used to work there

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: While you're in Dublin, I recommend taking the train up to Howth (or just driving there I suppose). It was the surprise hit of my trip there last year. You can take a boat out to Ireland's Eye (be sure to get out and walk around rather than just staying on the boat), grab some food around the town port, walk the cliff walk, then see Howth Castle and a dolmen nestled in a rhododendron garden.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2397142
The National Museum of Ireland was pretty cool. Lots of Stone Age antiques and some preserved bodies pulled from bogs. I did some whiskey tour where they gave us all 5 very generous shots at the end and that got me feeling great for the morning.

If you end up going to Galway and have the time for a day trip, I'd recommend taking the ferry to Inishmore. You can get there in the morning, bike the whole island and leave in the late afternoon. There's a lot of ruins scattered around the island that you can walk around in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you're interested in Irish military history, you should go to the museum at Collins Barracks. Admission is free and the tram (luas) has a stop specifically for it, called "museum".

>>2397438
If you're going to the Cliffs of Moher and the Aran islands, you can get a ferry from Doolin which is a ten minute drive from the cliffs. It might be more convenient for you to do this depending on what you have planned. You can see a lot of Inis Oírr in a few hours but you'd need most of the day for Inis Mór.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Czech attitude towards pretty much anything is "I don't give a shit just don't bother me". That goes for weed, it's not technically legal there but there are tons of head shops and references to weed around Prague. I haven't tried getting any over there but I'm guessing you could ask in one of the head shops, or try your luck on a dating app. Otherwise bars like the ones already mentioned are a good bet. Whenever I've smoked weed in other European countries it's been from the Czech Republic and it was good stuff.

Brno is a cool city, not nearly as touristy as Prague. I stayed there for a few nights and went to Moravsky Krumlov to see Alfons Mucha's masterpiece on display in a 900 year old castle. Also the ossuaries are pretty wild.

Cesky Krumlov is beautiful, definitely recommend spending a couple nights there if you like old castles. Also Hluboka nad Vltavou is one of the most beautiful castles in the country and it's not far.

Pilsen is cool but definitely more of a "locals-only" vibe except in the touristy spots like the Pilsner Urquell brewery. The beer and food is pretty exceptional.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391105
If you're used to USA or UK prices then the entirety of the Czech Republic will feel very affordable to you, unless you're trying to stay in high end AirBnbs/hotels and only eat at tourist trap restaurants. For $50 to $100 USD/night you should be able to find very comfortable places to stay in good locations, and I'm sure you can find cheaper stays than that if you really dig.

I think every single restaurant meal I ate in the Czech Republic was less than $15 USD, and that would probably get you an appetizer + entrée + at least one large beer. Otherwise, I would go to a grocery store in the morning and get some bread for like $1.50, some cheese for $2, some meat for $2 and some apples for $2 and be set for the day. Bus, train and tram tickets are extremely affordable, I don't think I've ever paid more than $10 and that was for a longer train ride.

In restaurants make sure you understand how tipping works - for example, after you ask to pay, the waiter will bring the card machine to your table, tell you that the price is 250 Kc, and then you have to say "please make it 300" or whatever you want. I think 10-15% is adequate for a tip there.

>>2389763
you should definitely visit at least 1 castle and do a castle tour, I've been to 10+ and was never disappointed
some even have ren faire style larpers do shows in the castle grounds
people will recommend Karlštejn, the castle itself is nice but the town is a tourist trap, so visit literally any castle that isn't Karlštejn, Prague Castle or Krumlov
you should also go hiking, the ideal case is you make friends with colleagues and visit their "chalupa", or go kayaking/biking/camping in a tent if you're into that
in summer/autumn you can go mushroom picking and hopefully get invited by a colleague for ovocné knedlíčky (fruit dumplings) which is the best Czech food that you can't get in restaurants
you can also try going to the opera at National Theater or Estates Theater in Prague, tickets are very cheap compared to elsewhere, shows almost every night, and the opera houses themselves are really beautiful
even if you don't listen to classical music it might still be fun to mingle with a classy crowd
Black Light Theater is fun too

>>2394137
Look into all the historic things you can see, plenty of Wampanoag museums and culture still around, check out their festivals. There's a lot of nature too, see lakes, marshes, woods, beaches. You will enjoy four distinct seasons. In summer it does get busier but you can easily avoid tourist places. If you know locals they can show you private beaches. Plenty of seafood, the local dish is clam showder. The stores have fresh lobster in them if you want to cook yourself. Whale watching is the major summer activity, whales are really cool. Please try local ice cream, bagels with cream cheese, and clam chowder. If you go out there's a renaissance fair each year, King Richard's fair. If you want fresh apples or pumpkins hit up the orchards or pumpkin patches come autumn. Cranberries are a local product so get cranberry juice, and in the winter the bogs freeze over and you can skate on them. And if you go up to Boston, try to museum of science, and the duck boats. Also randomly I recommend the Christmas Tree Shop, the one by the bridge. All holidays are very festive, Easter especially.

My advice is since it is expensive to find a small place, things close early so don't expect a popping night life, and know it's safe enough people often don't lock doors but never be naive.

After the interview however, I get a response from the recruiter saying they will make me an offer, but for only $100,000 because they didn't think I was at the high level of experience get to the $150,000. I did the cost of living calculation and at my current job of making $95,000 in the area I live, if I were to take the $100,000 in Hawaii it would be more like $44,000 where I live now. I told the recruiter I wasn't interested and moved on.
A few days later I get an email saying the company would like to offer $140,000 now. I basically told them to get fucked since I wasn't allowed to negotiate salary, they shouldn't either.

The salaries in IT for Hawaii will always be low since they will lean on the appeal that its in Hawaii. That shine will fade quick since you'll realize your purchasing power is very, very low since everything costs a shitton.

>>2396432
I was there in October and was shocked at the inflation. Definitely not a cheap place anymore. Euro Prices for third world experience. The metro is packed and uncomfortable but still normally better than getting a taxi due to traffic. There are lots of nice cafes - you have to try Turkish coffee for the experience, but I wasn't a big fan of it as it often has gritty bits in it. The blue Mosque was under renovation and so couldn't see anything inside and was a waste of time. IMO Fatith mosque is better and has a great view looking to the Galata tower.

Do a bosphorus cruise, time at sunset for best experience. Old town is touristy but generally a good place to base yourself really. I stayed half in this area and the other half over looking taksim square. I preferred the former. If you like palaces id recommend Dolmabahçe Palace - it was pretty neat. Hagia is worth linking up for and even though the line was insane when I joined it, it actually moved quite fast so dont be too put off; they have it down pat. Unlike the line for Topkapi palace to get a ticket and then audio guide which took an hour and a half - also you must bring passport or like 100 euros as security for most of these palaces/museums.


The Grand bazaar is cool for the architecture and experience, but dont buy anything there. Tourist trap on steroids and most stuff you have get half the price 2 streets over.


Also, if gay and wanting to use grindr; get a vpn or use a euro e-sim or something as the government blocks grindr.

The Galata bridge is scam central - the old shoe shine trick etc

I live 10 minutes from MIA

The only decent neighborhood near the airport is where I live, Coral Gables. It's mostly wealthy South Americans with a nice little shopping area called the Miracle Mile. Couple bars and a bunch of restaurants. If you're looking to party, it's not the place to go. It's just quiet and chill over here.

Everything else anywhere near the airport is a dump. Nothing but trash Cubans. Shitty drivers and terrible people. Good Latin food though if you really want it.

If you want nice beaches, I'd recommend going north. Anything around Ft. Lauderdale will be ok. South Beach is beautiful, but unless you get out there early, parking is nonexistent and the whole area is over run with darkie tourists shooting and robbing each other.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1. Make sure all of your devices are encrypted and require a startup password (a good, long password, not some "Password123" bullshit) before you can access them. Your phone should have this feature unless it's some giga poorfag brick phone or something. You might need to make sure it's turned on in the settings. For a Windows computer you can use Bitlocker or Veracrypt. For Mac there's FileVault. All of these programs are simple to set up and secure enough for any normal circumstance. You can encrypt flash drives with Veracrypt too.
2. Make sure your all devices are completely off (not sleep mode etc) before you enter the airport/border checkpoint. This shit won't work if they can just FaceID, fingerprint scan, unlock pin etc their way into your device. This is essential, it must be off.
3. If they ask you unlock any of your devices, just say no. I'm sure they'll be dicks about it and maybe they'll seize the device but they can't arrest you for not giving up a password. Just hold firm and tell them to fuck off.
BONUS: Set up Drivestrike (easy to set up, costs $1.50 a month) on your devices so you can remote wipe them if they get seized.

This should be good enough for any normie who just wants to protect his privacy. If you're doing some high level espionage shit maybe they have some secret NSA methods to get around all of this but the border wagie isn't going to be doing all of that to your iPhone. Also remember, just because you're not at the border doesn't mean you're not "at the border." The USA has inland border checkpoints where they can search your shit as if you were going though customs even though you're on US soil. Make sure your devices are encrypted/off when you pass through these too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378776
This sounds about right.

You can make India as cheap or as expensive as you'd like. Personally, I think $50-60 per day is a good range for travelers who want to be reasonably comfortable and not have to constantly pinch pennies.

For about $50-60 per day, you can get:
>reasonably nice hotel room (2-3 stars) or Airbnb
>mix of street food and mid-range restaurant food
>private and public transportation (Uber+Metro)
>enough money to have a few drinks in the evening or on the weekends
>money for entrance fees and general sightseeing
>souvenirs and okay-quality handicrafts

You can obviously survive on much, much less money. If you're staying in a hostel dorm, for instance, you probably don't need more than $20-25 per day, assuming the dorm bed costs $8-10.

Fuck--you can basically live on $1-5 per day if you Couchsurf/stay in mosques/stay in gurudwaras and only eat street food. It's fucking India, most people outside of big cities are living on like $2-3 per day. Just don't expect that you can maintain a comfortable standard of living on these sorts of budgets.

However, I do think any strict budget of less than $20 per day is going to entail some significant sacrifices, especially for people who want to do adventure sports, visit a lot of monuments, etc. When you're spending closer to $50-60+ per day, you won't have the budget to stay in a 4- or 5-star hotel, but you can do pretty much everything else without having to think twice about your finances (within reason, of course).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378901
As a quick follow-up, if you're traveling in the country, money obviously goes a lot further. I regularly travel to East-Central India and stay in homestays. In one of the villages I frequent, there are like 2-3 different homestays. The rates are like:
>$7-8 per night for an entire mud house (sounds primitive but actually p comfortable)
>$3-4 per day for food (3 meals per day)
>$8-9 for a guide / someone to drive you around wherever you want (not necessary, but helpful if you want to visit hardcore ooga-booga areas etc)
>$3-4 per day for motorbike, fuel separate (I usually take my own bike)

so for about $20-30 per day, you have accommodation, transportation, and food completely covered

also worth bearing in mind that a lot of dirt-cheap hotels simply do not accept foreign guests, especially in smaller cities in rural areas. this has much less to do with xenophobia than local law, which requires anyone hosting a foreign national to submit a report (Form C) to law enforcement within 24 hours of the guest's arrival. most hotels just don't want to bother, since you have to create an account on the e-FRRO website and it takes like 10-20 minutes on a shitty internet connection to enter all the info

ofc, it's still india so you can accomplish just about anything with the right amount of money + patience

If you're staying or working in a more central area, paying an additional $200-300 out-of-pocket should net you a spacious, modern property.

>How easy is it to travel to other parts of India from Mumbai?
Mumbai is a Tier-1 city and Alpha global city. It has an international airport with flights across the country. You can also take the train to most places. There are regular buses--across a variety of budgets--running to other cities in Maharashtra, Goa, and so forth.

>And how easy is it to make friends/date as a Westerner?
Completely depends on you. Making friends in India is reasonably easy. However, the sorts of people who are most likely to approach you in the street will be interested in you because you're "different." You can sometimes meet decent people this way, but you might not have anything in common. Furthermore, they might simply want to show you off as their "cool foreign friend."

Dating is a slightly different story. Living in India longer-term makes dating easier, especially if you're looking for something serious--many women won't want to go out with someone who's only here for a few weeks or a few months.

Other than that, well--it completely fucking depends on you. You can certainly find White fetishists in a city like Mumbai--girls who only date White men, and will sleep with any reasonably attractive foreigner. They're a very small percentage of the overall population, but if you look half-decent, they'll proactively seek you on dating apps.

I met some of these women when I was single, and they are fucking insufferable. But if you're just looking to get laid, they'll give you what you want.

Samefag who lives in India.

I've traveled to many Naxal-affected villages. You can't just "visit" a Naxalite camp. Outside of a scarce few areas, the Maoists do not maintain any permanent military outposts. During the monsoon, they usually entrench themselves in sympathetic villages that cannot be easily accessed by outsiders, including the Indian security forces. For the rest of the year, and especially in the winter, they camp in rugged jungles during the day and then move into hamlets for provisions and support at night.

While the Naxalites do have something akin to a "parallel government" in parts of Dandakaranya--do a Google search for "Abujmarh"--outsiders cannot simply stroll in for a tour. You will almost certainly be detained and turned around by the CRPF, District Reserve Guard, or another state security force. Even if you pay a local to help you around established checkpoints, you wouldn't get much farther inland without a genuine contact and legitimate connections.

Here's what would most probably happen: once you enter a so-called "liberated zone," you'd be stopped by sympathetic villagers or members of a local Maoist militia. You probably can't speak Hindi, so you wouldn't be able to explain why you're there. Even if you can speak Hindi, you wouldn't be allowed to travel within a Naxal-dominated area unless you'd received prior "permission" from higher-ranking Maoists. You'd be kept overnight and then told to leave the area in the morning.

Conceivably, you could just go "hiking" across Bailadila and "accidentally" end up across the Sukma border. But even if you came across the Naxalites, they wouldn't be willing to entertain some random, retarded foreigner.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2396766
cont.
You'd be interrogated, held overnight, and--again--told to piss off at first light. In a worst-case scenario, they could use you as a bargaining chip (although the Naxalites have only held foreign tourists for ransom once in the last 50-60 years--and that kidnapping was staged by a former Naxalite commander who had already been kicked out of the main Maoist organization for provoking communal violence in Odisha).

If you know the right people--journalists, villagers, and so forth--they could take you to heavily-affected areas. But if any word got back to any government official that your stupid ass was actively trying to meet Maoists, you'd almost certainly be either deported or restricted from ever re-entering India.

I cannot adequately express how heavily militarized certain parts of Jharkhand, Odisha, and Chhattisgarh area. In so-called "hardcore" Naxal areas, there are police encampments every 2-3 kilometers. If you try to circumvent said encampments, you will probably be stopped by villagers. In certain parts of Abujmarh and adjacent areas, there is also a minute risk that you could step on a landmine or improvised explosive device.

It's really not a good idea.

However, you can still very easily visit peripheral areas as a tourist--and that's something I'd really recommend doing, because many parts of Chhattisgarh and Jharkhand have incredibly unique tribal cultures. Tribal people are usually very honest, very cordial people--they won't stare at you or ask for selfies, and will treat you with the utmost respect if you show the same to them. It's also a good way to gain a basic understanding of on-the-ground conditions without exposing yourself to risks you don't understand.

Generally very safe, with some exceptions. Just do a bit of research on the places you're going beforehand.

In parts of North India--especially rural Bihar, Jharkhand, and Madhya Pradesh--there are still gangs of bandits, who are colloquially called "dacoits." The usual advice in such areas is to avoid any and all travel after sunset. Of course, you'd probably be fine if you were taking public transportation or simply walking around the periphery of a village.

Just be aware that finding accommodation in smaller towns can be difficult, since many budget hotels aren't willing to fill out the paperwork needed to host foreign guests.

However, SBI is one of a very few banks that doesn't typically charge foreign card-holders any withdrawal fee, provided that you're smart enough to decline the dynamic currency conversion offer.

cont.
Certain categories of trains have higher priority and better service than others. Rajdhani and Shatabdi trains, for instance, are usually better-maintained and considerably more punctual than lower-priority trains. I have no clue about services between Pondicherry and Kanchipuram. I doubt it's a very long ride, and I doubt you'd have to deal with much inconvenience.

Overall, you'll usually be at least somewhat comfortable if you book a berth in:
>1AC: highest category of travel, have to share a private, lockable "coupe" with one other passenger. Good service on most Rajdhani and Shatabdi trains, variable on others (air-conditioned)
>2AC: 2x2 berths in main cabin, 2x2 berth on the side (air-conditioned)
>3AC: 3x3 berths in main cabin, 2x2 berth on the side (air-conditioned)

Sleeper is non-AC and very inexpensive, but you'll have to deal with a bit more hassle in terms of retarded passengers, regular beggars, and obnoxious shemale beggars. Non-AC and general can be a clusterfuck, but you'll probably have tons of random people to talk to.

I'd recommend looking for whatever /n/ thread the other anon mentioned.

Just be aware that booking last-minute train tickets as a foreign tourist can be a pain in the ass, since most booking websites don't accept foreign credit cards. I think the IRCTC website only lets you make payments through the ATOM portal more than 48-72 hours in advance. However, they have a new Amex payment portal, and I've been able to use my U.S.-issued Amex card on that without any issues. You can sometimes circumvent payment restrictions on third-party websites using AmazonPay, but some booking agencies, like RedBus, recnetly closed this loophole and now block wallet payments made in foreign currencies.

(the ATOM portal may now be defunct--I didn't see the option the last time I paid for train tickets. Again, I have a local bank account, so some of the shit I'm saying may have been true a few years ago but have since changed)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2396772
It's a long story, homie.

The Naxalite insurgency started in a northern district of West Bengal in 1967 before spreading southward toward Kolkata and other urban areas. However, the early Naxalite movement was effectively curbed before and during the political Emergency of the 1970s. During this period, many Naxal sympathizers and cadres were arrested, imprisoned, or summarily executed.

While the initial movement was waning in Bengal, hardcore Maoist sympathizers began actively surveying other regions for the location of a potential "guerrilla base." So far as I can recall, in Maoist war strategy, a guerilla base is an isolated, inaccessible area, from which militants can amass strength and began waging a protracted war of attrition against the urban, industrial state.

Since many early Naxalite cadres were Telugu speakers, they began making inroads into isolated tribal communities in East-Central India. The Gonds, for example, are among the largest tribes in the region; their language doesn't have any widely-used written alphabet. However, since Gondi is somewhat similar to Telugu, the Telugu-speaking cadres were able to gradually learn the language and begin "fixing" certain problems relating to corruption and resource exploitation.

Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, the Naxalites began establishing a significant presence in the historical Dandakaranya region. Much of this region has been neglected by governments for hundreds of years, from the Mughals to the Raj to the early, post-Independence administrations.

Today, the Maoists find the most support among tribal people--people who might not understand or care about the Maoists' ideological values, but believe that their lifestyles and cultures are being threatened by the state.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2396777
cont.
For context, the most heavily-affected regions, in Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh, are incredibly rich in mineral resources. When the anti-Maoist Salwa Judum militia formed in 2006, tens of thousands of tribal people were displaced from villages that--oh so coincidentally--happened to be of interest to domestic and international mining corporations.

At this point, it's less about ideology, and more about tribal people trying to preserve their rights to "jal, jangal, jameen" (water, jungle, land). I've visited villages wherein the locals used to support the Maoists until they successfully petitioned the government for land titles, after which they cut contact with the guerillas.

If you're interested in the topic, check out "Hello, Bastar" by Rahul Pandita and "Nightmarch" by Alpa Shah. They're both very informative books written by people who have worked extensively in Maoist-affected areas. They're also written for lay audiences, unlike many publications on the topic.

Just be aware that most writings on the insurgency tend to be at least somewhat biased toward one side or the other; the same is true for media coverage. You'll find a lot of left-wing whacko academics who suck the Naxalites' figurative cocks, and just as many right-wing nationalists who are incapable of understanding that Maoist violence is underscored by genuine grievance.

tl;dr: early Maoist sympathizers, especially in the late 1960s and early 1970s, were actual ideologues. Today, most Maoist sympathizers are tribal people who want to protect their land rights and social/cultural autonomy. Most of them don't have any meaningful understanding of Maoist ideology, and simply see the Naxalites as a convenient buffer to state encroachment.

(it's worth mentioning that the Maoists actively hamper assistive development efforts, preventing tribal people from having easy access to effective healthcare and educational institutions--it's not a very complicated, very delicate situation)

>Use skyscanner.
>Search your flight on the 'whole month' option (try multiple months as well).
>Select the cheapest combination of days.
>Use carry-on luggage only.
>Do not purchase any extras for the flight.
>Be prepared to spend upwards of 6 hours in an airport during a layover.

What I have learnt:
Don't bother trying to save an extra $20 by 'mixing and matching' airlines when you only have a few hours between the flights. If the earlier flight is delayed and you miss your next flight (more likely than you'd think) the airlines probably won't help you. Mixing and matching airlines is acceptable when you have days between flights.
If the flights you're looking at have unfortunately long layovers (16 hours+), see about staying in the layover destination for a day or two and getting the flight to your real destination later. You do this by booking a return flight to the layover destination and a return flight from the layover destination to the real destination.
Most of the time cheap airlines are perfectly fine and anyone who wants to spend an extra $500+ just to get a shitty meal and see shitty movies through a shitty chair screen for 12 hours is an idiot. Purchase a good phone battery bank, put some games or movies on your phone and enjoy, being a little bored for a few hours is absolutely worth the money saved by flying cheap.
Cheap airlines are known for not refunding your ticket so don't buy the ticket if you aren't sure you will be going unless you're willing to take the risk.

>Is it actually a good city to live in?

As someone who actually just got done scratching it off my list of possible places to move to, IMO not really.

Pro's:
>low housing costs
>spread out enough to not be too cramped
>all four seasons
>fairly broad job infrastructure
>highway can get you around quickly
>fairly low cost of living compared to other places
Con's
>low pay without maintaining a gov job, healthcare, or remote job
>old houses will all but require some renovations or pay out the ass for something new
>car basically required, not the worst but winter can make a bike/motorcycle useless with how shit the roads get
>downtown is pretty grabage and in the middle of another migration COVID did a number on it
>job market is far more susceptible to recessions

If you can basically buy a house out right you should be okay, just know that the job market is pretty meh depending on the sector you work in

Been living in Columbus for nearly 10 years now so I know the city pretty well. It's not even remotely similar to Baltimore, I'm not sure where you heard that from. It's generally a good city to live in imho. If you're a libtard don't come here, there's enough of you faggots here already.

PROS:
>affordable property relative to other larger cities (altough getting pricey quick)
>relatively low cost of living
>good number of well paying white collar jobs in government, insurance, banking, education, and tech
>the freeway system is really well laid out and traffic isnt that bad even at rush hour
>great arts scene with many galleries across the city and a good music scene. You get touring acts from all genres stop here
>food scene is great too, Columbus punches above its wait in this category. You can everything from street food to ethnic to fine dining. There are like 4 different food halls and a kajillion breweries. You will never ever run out of new places to eat/drink.
>it's a growing city with a booming population, the number of new buildings ive seen go up in the last decade is staggering
>there's a lot of really nice neighborhoods in the center and great suburbs
>there are no homeless encapments all over the place like on the left coast. That shit is not allowed
>great parks

CONS:
>homeless people are allowed to panhandle for some reason so you still see them at major intersections and freeway offramps. Gross.
>very corrupt city government
>it's a dumping ground for somali refugees so they're all over
>most of the city is not walkable, just a few neighborhoods
>public transport (buses) are bad
>the only pro sports are soccer and hockey (and minor league baseball), you want to watch anything else it's going to be Ohio State or a trip to Cincinnati or Cleveland
>most of the new apartment buildings are cheaply and hastily constructed, sit near railroad tracks, and are overpriced

posts.com: I would say it is the most overrated. Try and remember that being overrated does not mean it’s terrible or even not good. It means it’s rated higher than it actually is. France is considered like the top or top 3 destinations by a ton of people, and I don’t think it’s that. A lot of this is due to the fact it USED to be that good, but isn’t anymore. Paris is now kind of a dump, it used to be great. Many of the places that were awesome because they were “untouched” are now flooded with tourists. Still a great country for tourism generally speaking but equal to tons of other places in Europe. There are also places that are in fact cheaper and just as good. If it continues its downward spiral it will be in the bottom half of Europe destinations before 2030, but you still hear people talk like it’s still top tier. So yes quite overrated

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Maybe because when people think about France they only think about Paris. Paris may be overrated but it's still undeniably an exceptional city. Some of the best museums in the world, architectural beauty, and in some places you can still sort of imagine the Paris of the 1930s/1950s.
The rest of France offers a lot of variety. High mountains, Atlantic thin sand beaches, Mediterranean sea, alabaster cliffs, hilly countryside dotted by medieval castles and prehistoric caves. Diversity in food because of all the different climates in the country.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390893
I've done two families together and the understanding that we could split up meant a big argument just resulted in splitting for a day and joining back up after having cooled off. My scattershot advice:

Try to get people to say what they want to do as early as possible. Some people may want to watch Fantasmic, some may want a themed dinner, etc. Finding out late in the day can lead to arguments.
Sort out a basic itinerary early. Allow for flexy days if someone wants to go to Gatorworld, do an airboat ride, there are multiple days with activities not set in stone where you can split up for the whole day.
Do not go to Magic Kingdom on the weekend. Chances are you're flying in on the weekend, they will want their first day to be at the Magic Kingdom. Do not do it, tell them how that park is hell on weekends.
Try to stick together for the "main" days, the more people riding on things together, the better.
Sort out your toilet breaks and minimise them. You waste so much fucking time in big groups because of constant long toilet breaks.
Don't over pressure people to go on rides they can't take, not only may they have a miserable time, they may believe they're going to keep getting pressured for other rides they don't want to go on.
Continuing on that let people go on other rides whilst they wait, you can meet after.
Try to avoid quiet people getting dominated: "Lol no we don't want to go on the Little Mermaid ride!" "oh... ok". Especially likely to happen to people who can't take big coasters. Try to stop dominant voices getting into the habit of speaking for the group
Avoid any people becoming the "+2". Easy for the same people to always be the last ones in the line who go in a different car from everyone else on rides.
Sort out phones, everyone must be contactable. Parks have free wifi everywhere if people don't have roaming.
Don't make people reliant on "the group" for transport

Get everyone to get the My Disney Experience app and link it all together.

It's a technicality. Disney even coined the term "theme park". This has nothing to do with Disney adults. My original point was people shit on regional parks by saying Walt took his daughters to one and came up with the idea for Disneyland. But none of these parks existed, the parks that existed back then were like Coney Islands and trolley parks and carnivals.

Some of those old parks became larger regional parks, but most popular regional parks were OPENLY copying the Disneyland model. For example, Angus Wynne, the creator of Six Flags, created Six Flags Over Texas after visiting Disneyland to make something similar but themed to Texas. These parks borrowed Disneyland design elements like the themed lands, hub and spoke layout, garbage cans everywhere, and had cheap facsimiles of popular attractions. Theming was kitschy but so was early Disneyland until the expansions in the late 60s and onward.

You don't need to be an autistic circumcised dickhead about it. Fuck off

>What do you think is a reasonable price outlay for 2 people going to Orlando (Dis/Uni) for 2 weeks
Depends where you want to stay.
Tickets alone will cost you basically £1k per person if you want Disney, Universal and Seaworld.
Flights will be upwards of £2k total depending on time of day/year.
Hotels start at around £800 per person for a value place like Universal's Endless Summer resort, but I prefer staying in a Villa which start at £1200.
There was a nice privately owned Villa I stayed at twice so try looking into that.
https://floridavillawithpool.co.uk/

posts.com:
Is Car Hire even necessary for Florida?
If you stay onsite in Disney or Universal, Im assuming youll just be getting an Uber to the other main parks.
If you stay at Disney, just get the bus to Disney Springs and get an uber to wherever you want to go along International Drive, or hop on the I-Trolley to cut down on costs.

Obviously if you stay off site at a Villa youre probably looking at a minimum of $40 per day with Uber, so even taking a flat rate of 2 weeks thats 12 days coming in at about $500. So even if car rental is around $600-800 you could probably make uber work in your favour, allowing for extra trips per day and still coming under the total cost of a car (that also requires petrol & parking fees in places)

I think what you'll find, if you're a first timer, is that there's probably more you'll want to do offsite than you think there is and then sticking to a predetermined uber budget will be difficult. There are tons of places to see and eat at in that area and even more if you're willing to drive a little further (such as Cape Canaveral). Being able to do that on your schedule or whim maximizes your own time which, on a vacation, seems worth it. If you're going to be there a week or more, I can't imagine not having a rental car, at least for part of the stay.

Don't forget that Disney buses are notorious for taking a long time to get around with. As I said, it could be worth it to you to pay more to skip waiting around at bus stops.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2395494

Alton Towers has some incredible coasters, but its entirely dependant on the context.

For the UK, its clearly the leading theme park.
Compared to Americas biggest parks, its alright.

Nemesis has closed. They are doing a complete track rebuild. It was starting to show its age, so the new track should be much smoother. Im not sure if its a new layout, or just new steel.

Rita, Queen of Speed is pretty awesome. Although its very short, and compared to things like Top Speed Dragsters its fairly tame.

Thirteen, has its moments, although when you ride it, the track looks so thing and frail you can be amazed it stands up.

Oblivion has its charm. The worlds first vertical drop coaster (even if it was only an 89 degree drop). But compared to Shiekra or Baron, its just a drop. The ride will be over very quick. Theres no other elements.

Smiler is hands down their best ride. Its so impressive to see so many elements crammed into such a small space. I wish more parks would do this. You dont always need height and speed. Well executed elements in close proximity to one another are great.

Air, or Galactica is fairly boring. You spend a lot of time upside down on your back, and miss a lot of the layout. Sure it feels a bit like your flying, but keep me face down for most of it. Its a poor mans version of Manta

It's a shame that UK parks are not only massively seasonal but that for half the time they're open, the weather is miserable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395621
>>2395621
Pretty much this, it’s all about immersion. Switch your devices over to Spanish (you don’t have to download a keyboard, just can set the proprietary keyboard to switch between whatever languages you need). The only app I really used was conjugation nation, which has a finite number of tenses and verbs, but it compliments learning grammar well.

you can listen to podcasts and watch content based around slanish-learning, but after about 3-4 months you’re gonna wanna switch to content targeting native speakers. Netflix has commissioned a lot of spanish language series due the success of La casa de papel/money heist, and my teachers always insisted to NOT use any subtitles. The point of watching that kind of content isn’t to practice reading lines, it’s to understand context, phrasing, colloquialisms and conversational flow.

I also subscribed to new channels on YouTube like el pais and bbc mondo. I listen to a shitload of music with spanish lyrics, not only does it help with vocabulary, but native speaking’s think it’s crazy when you can recite the lyrics to a banda song or even know about a group like hombres G. If you like sports watch La liga and NFL offers Highlights in Mexican spanish.

I went from tourist levels to nearly fluent (for you euros A2 to B2/C1) in about 9 months, but that involved 6 months of intensive lessons in Spain/Colombia. If anybody decides to go that route DO NOT fall back to hanging out with your classmates and speaking English. You will go nowhere and forget everything the moment you go home.

dude, don't even bother wasting your time if you're not going to commit. If you're gonna want to learn the language, you're going to have to crack open a book, you're going to have to learn grammar, you're going to have to start listening to simple material (ie children shows, baby speak) and work your way up. It never failed that each Carnival cruise I went on had at least three gigantic black family reunions (as evidenced by the t-shirts). Royal Caribbean's ship at least provided some space from the less-than-desirable people, who were also fewer in number as well. The onboard dining options were stellar and I never felt too rushed to do anything.

As far as geography goes, the Caribbean is a good place to start

I work on cruise ships, currently on vacation, my next vacation is in March.

The previous anons talking about fjords are onto something, Alaska, Norway and New Zealand take on a whole different dimension when you see if from the ocean. Those would be the only places I’d visit on a cruise,with the exception of the Greek isles and French Polynesia. Everywhere else is better on land or not worth visiting.

Small towns can be alright, but sometimes the cruise planners are filling in random ports so they can sell it as unique, this particularly true in places like South/central America and Africa that essentially are industrial ports and require excursions to actually see anything. Also if it’s really small the ship might not actually dock but anchor, and tendering is a shitty experience, I’m glad they pay me to put up with it.

If you wanna enjoy activities the actual ship, go with big (4,500 passengers +) and book a week wherever is cheap/ convenient for you. Anything smaller than 3000 guests is gonna be on the «quieter « side.

posts.com:
>>2393652
This.

One of my best friends was in the Peace Corps. He was actually stationed in central Zanzibar for about 3 years. I visited him for a few months in 2017. The interior of the island is largely comprised of impoverished villages. There isn’t much to do or see. However, visiting isn’t unsafe. Small children might ask you for money (or throw stones at you). If you can speak Swahili, they’ll treat you like a human. Otherwise, you’re a walking money dispenser.

I spent my birthday there and rented a motorcycle for a few days. Riding around Zanzibar was fun, although the drivers are the worst I’ve ever seen (and I say that as someone who now lives in India).

TBQH it’s a pleasant place to spend a few days, but there isn’t much to do outside of Stone Town and the popular beaches. It’s also all-around pretty safe, but armed robberies sometimes happen after sunset on isolated stretches of beach adjacent to resorts and planned parties.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2394865
I have some friends in Fukui but it's really a wonderful city. A lot of people recommend the dinosaur museum (which i think is being renovated right now unfortunately) but it's also right next to Echizen which was at one point one of the central hubs of traditional industry in feudal japan. There are a lot of museums such as the bamboo museum and specialty shops for their world renowned cutlery. Also within train distance are the Tojinbo cliffs, which are a neat sightseeing spot with a couple of shops around it. There's also a bunch of seafood markets here and there which have Echizen snow crab, which is supposed to be some of the best in Japan. Fukui itself might be more of a standard city, it has a few castles but they have a restaurant chain called Europa which has some of the best tonkotsu i've ever eaten. In August they also have a big fireworks festival if you're into that. Please visit if you have the chance, it should be a stop on the JR West line if you have a pass.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2394674
Have you looked into renting jiko bukken (事故物件) apartments?They're apartments where the previous tenant died in, either murder, accident, or suicide. According to Japanese law the landlord has to disclose to the potential new tenants about the death of the previous tenant which makes the property less valuable due to superstitions. These apartments are thus cheaper and there's less competition to get them as the natives would rather stay away from those apartments.

posts.com: If I’m going from the Chuo line to the Osaka loop line do I need to pay separate train fares for each line with my IC card? Or is there a way to just pay for it at the end of my osaka loop line and get some sort of discount?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395529
1) if you need to change trains and you go from one station to another you need to pay twice. The first time you tap a card when you're going in to the station you "sign in" and then you tap again once you leave the station you get off you "sign out" and the payment is displayed on the machine. If you change trains on the same station you only pay at the last station you get off on.
2) If you're going from a JR line to a local line or vice versa you generally have to pay even if it is on the same station as you're traveling with two different companies, so in the end you'll pay twice.
3) There's usually no discount. You'll pay for the distance traveled, or some lines will have a flat rate but that's usually buses rather than trains
>pic rel. Osaka Metro line map showing Chuo line as an Osaka Metro line and Osaka Loop as a JR line
>read: You will have to pay twice

>I'm looking for an apartment because I'm staying in japan for a long while. Im not staying in a fucking airbnb for months. Airbnbs in japan are fucked since pre corona because of new laws so you're talking bs if you think you're saving money on airbnbs because the supply shock from laws means they're all expensive asf
I've recommended this company before, I used them a lot: https://residencetokyo.com/en/

Another anon replied with a company they used. I found the prices pretty comparable.

These places rent month-to-month all inclusive furnished apartments with no security deposit or hidden fees. You can pay by credit card and then cash in their offices once you're in Japan. The apartments are small but usually a 5min walk or so to the station. Keypad entry so you can arrive late at night and go straight to your place without meeting anyone. You're looking at about $1000/month (could be more, could be less), and that's a lot cheaper than almost any other option.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2396462
I've racked up $3700 for a 17 day trip, including direct flights, JR pass, and one 5* hotel stay.
You can get away with $400 for a hotel over 7 days in tokyo, but it's a tiny 11-13m2 room. Kinda keeps you out of the room, which is a great thing.

In your case I'd figure out what your main goals in tokyo are, then I'd pick a area to stay. I've chosen Ueno & Shinjuku/Shibuya since they seem connected well and they're close to places I'd like to visit.
Or go rouge by booking every type of a hotel (if you're travelling light). That should an unique experience.

Shimokitazawa (下北沢, Shimokitazawa) is a commercial and entertainment area in Kitazawa, Setagaya, Tokyo. It is located in the southwestern corner of the Kitazawa district, hence the name "Shimo-kitazawa" (literally lower Kitazawa). Also known as "Shimokita", the neighbourhood is well known for the density of small independent fashion retailers, cafes, theaters, bars and live music venues.

Somebody asked this question some time ago but Japan is one of the easiest places to find acceptable public toilets.
Almost every park will have a 24/7 public toilet, all department stores, malls, entertainment complexes, train stations and public offices will have toilets that are open to the public plus it's not hard to use the toilets of coffee shops and convenience stores if you show that you'll buy something afterwards.
The only caveat is that some of them are squat toilets and that you better carry some tissues just in case.

>>2396983
Have you rad up on your Japanese bicycle laws?
Short and simple:
>no bikes on trains unless they're foldable or fit in overhead (must also use a special bag for it)
>bikes are classed as light vehicles among mopeds
>certain bicycle offenses can carry a fine up to 1 million yen and/or a 30 day prison sentence, or if you're a foreigner you can be deported instead
>pedestrians get priority over cyclists even on bicycle lanes
That's just something to keep in mind. In any case it can be great fun

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395348

Lisbon is better, but don't sleep on Porto. Lisbon has more shit to do, especially in the daytime. Lisbon has a relaxed, friendly vibe. Lisbon is closer to Algarve in the south. Huge variety of food. Everything is centrally located and it's super simple to see a bunch of cool shit.

Porto is more of a working city. It's cheaper, the people can actually afford to live and work there. It's not pretentious, and has a gritty quality that's admirable. Lots of beauty on the water. Has more pubs, meat sandwiches, and people are like 35-50 years old in Porto whereas they might be 20-35 in Lisbon. Porto is in the north and is near the vineyard region (Duoro valley) if you're into taking a boat cruise into a vineyard landscape

If you have time you should totally see both, but Lisbon for me was better. Lisbon you can definitely stay a week in to see the whole thing. Porto you could see everything in 3-4 days.

posts.com: /biz/let here, leaning on /trv/ for some guidance. Please share some tips for Mardi Gras. Arriving in NOLA on the 18th of February, will be there for 5 days. Anons who have gone, share stories. How do my friends and I have a great time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2389662
1. Go to Antoine’s. In the French Quarter Fine dining, French cuisine. Do NOT dress casual. Very cheap, complete meal with champagne should cost around 35-40$ if you get the premium items.
2. Johnny’s Po Boys is kind of mid but if you aren’t planning on going outside of New Orleans to taste traditional creole food it’s great.
3. If possible go to a outlying city such as Baton Rouge and get some Boudin (pronounced Boudan and locals get uppity if you pronounce it boudin and will correct you while seething)
3. Take ghost tour of cemetery. It’s stupid but fun.
4. Do NOT book at the Omni or the the W Hotel (Omni is shoebox+ expensive)people will scream and throw shit and you can hear it all night at the W) if cheap enough, go to the Westin. That’s the best place to go and only 5-8 minute walk to French quarter and 10-15 to bourbon street.
5. Go to Cafe Du Monde, but bring a drink beforehand. Drinks are ridiculously expensive there and the beignets will fry you like a motherfucker. Wait times will be anywhere from 15-50 minutes so plan accordingly.
6. Go to Fritzel’s. It’s a jazz club and very kino. Has the authentic New Orleans feel and vibe. Be early or you will not get a seat.
7. Do not take up any people who offer free drinks or anything on the street. They will hustle you. Don’t be a retard and you will be fine.

- Saturday: Fly

Rome:
- Sunday: Pantheon, 4 Rivers Fountain, Santa Maria in Vallicella, Trevi Fountain, San Luigi dei Francesi, The Church Of S. M. Sopra Minerva, Santa Maria sopra Minerva

- Monday: Colosseum, Roman Forum, St. John Lateran, San Pietro in Vincoli, Victor Emmanuel II Monument, Capitoline Museum, Basilica San Clemente, San Giuseppe dei Falegnami, Saint Mary Major

- Tuesday: Vatican — St. Peter’s (climb dome), Vatican Museums

- Wednesday: Galleria Borghese, Santa Maria del Popolo, Santa Maria della Vittoria, Spanish Steps, Twin Churches

Pompeii & Naples:
- Thursday: Pompeii, Vesuvius Hike, Piazza Plebiscito (Basillica and Royal Palace), Capella Sansevero

Florence:
- Friday: Galleria dell'Accademia, Duomo (w/ dome), Piazza della Signoria, Ponte Vecchio, Uffizi, Santa Croce (Would also like to see Donatello’s David but probably not practical…)

Venice:
- Saturday: St. Mark’s Square, St. Marks Basilica, Doge’s Palace

- Sunday: Fly

Should I do 2 days in Florence and shove days 1 and 4 together in Rome? Any other suggestions for places to visit (or to not visit) or just general tips? Thanks

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390788
not that guy but i also like verona
one problem with italian tourist destinations is that the tourists attract people trying to make money off the tourists - not just cheap companies that dont care about their reputation but also gypsies and illegal immigrants wanting to sell you something for a euro(if you're lucky), but verona compared to the most famous cities in italy, is a little more chill in this regard but there is still the presence. infront of the main sights and shopping streets is obviously where it is most occuring, so side streets or non tourist spots are cool.
very comfy walkable city great architecture - every city has core streets that accumulate the most tourists but it is quite easy to find nice places to wander that are not overly crowded - i went in peak august holidays so maybe local italians were more inclined to be outside the city at the lakes/mountains/beaches.
there are not really famous museums compared to other cities. the core of the city has remnants of roman to medieval to renaissance to Napoleonic structures. surrounding the city are city walls with comfy grass/park areas aorund. but its also a medium sized city so it has young people who are trying modern service businesses in addition to the classic stuff - but also like every region in italy there are local specialties that are nice.

there is the roman amphitheatre in the middle of town
the old castle you can walk through but it has a museum
the large gardens on the hill above the river
Juliet's Balcony is the only tourist trap (there is no historical juliet..), but if you have a girl to impress it can be useful

but just like getting a gelato next to the river or chilling at a restaurant on the river bank are what i liked about it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390375
You wont have time for Naples and Pompei, especially not if you're taking the train and visiting those sites and then taking the train back in the same day.

Seeing as you are headed to Venice by train anyway it would make more sense to have two days for Firenze (absolutely worth it, best museums and art anywhere in the world). That way you see Rome, take the train to Firenze, and then the train to Venice, instead of taking a bunch of 3 hour train journeys back and forth several days in a row. You wont see everything you want to no matter how hard you try, so keep your schedule realistic.

Fly into Pisa and train to Cinque Terre for a couple of nights, before making my way to Florence, spending 4-5 nights there or potentially a couple in Siena, and finishing in Bologna. This requires backtracking between Cinque Terre and Pisa.

or

Flying to Venice and spending a night or two there, take the train to Verona and spend 1-2 nights there, and then to Florence with a day trip or two to Tuscan countryside. End in Bologna. This does require backtracking as Bologna is between Verona and Florence but it's only an extra 40 minutes on high speed rail.

Travelling with my girlfriend, decent budget for daily expenses and hotels.

Basically tossing up between Cinque Terre and more time in Florence/Tuscany vs Venice/Verona and a bit less time in Florence.

I'll just say that Bologna is really expensive as far as Italy goes and the city isn't all that interesting, I spent 3-4 days there and would have removed it from my itinerary if I were to do the trip again. Try to do a daytrip to Ravenna if you have time to see the churches and orthodox mosaics, some of the best you'll find in Italy.

3 nights in Firenze (two full days) should be considered an absolute minimum, and you should consider visiting Lucca instead of Pisa. Haven't been to Cinque Terre so I can't vouch for it in either direction, but Amalfi-coast and Positano which is similar was super touristy and I felt uncomfortable the entire time I was there. I think humanoids of the female gender tend to enjoy these places though. Maybe you could fly into Genoa to reduce the detours.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390375
I agree with the others saying that Napoli is too far out of the way to make sense, which is tough to say because I loved it there.
For Rome, I highly recommend a bit in the southern end of the city. Before the Colosseum, take the metro down to the Piramide station, right outside theres an awesome Roman early Imperial era pyramid that was incorporated into the city walls. Then a short walk away is Caracalla's baths which really shows massive Roman imperial architecture and life. Then a short walk past the circus maximus you get to the Colosseum area. Far more impressive than the overrated spanish steps and the like, but a fraction of the crowds.
If you have a bit more time in Rome, the Park of the Aqueducts is scenic and a bit awe inspiring, it's right near the Lucio Sestio metro station. That neighborhood is also a chill and modern area to see the new city.
Elsewhere in Rome, Ponte Palatino and the nearby transtiberium neighborhood is cool.
One busy day in Florence was enough for me personally. I planned on spending longer, but wanted to get out so took day trips out. Siena was one of my favorites.
Sounds like a good trip, enjoy!

>>2390375

Excellent itinerary. I'd recommend flying into Venice if you can, spend a couple of days there, and then start moving southernly, so you're not bouncing back and forth. I used the water taxi as a cheap boat tour of the Venice, which was pretty cool. Also a great thing to do at night is this ceviche tour where you get taken to various trattorias and pubs for a specialized appetizer and a matched wine. It was a unique experience and a lot of fun.

The Catacombs in Rome are a must-see imo

Toward the end of my trip, in Naples, I took the ferry for Ischia for a day and a night. On Ischia they have this centuries-old water park of about 50 volcanically-heated mineral pools, all of different temperatures, with a nice cafe at the top of the mountain and a private beach at the bottom. That was a nice way to unwind after a pretty hectic few weeks of sightseeing.
